example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over bed 2, Ms. Leila Haddad, 59 years old. She’s been admitted with a large pericardial effusion—likely secondary to metastatic breast cancer. She’s for pericardiocentesis this afternoon.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. How is she currently?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s hemodynamically stable but symptomatic—short of breath at rest, mild chest tightness, and fatigue. No syncope or hypotension. She’s on 2 L nasal prongs to maintain sats around 94%.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: What’s been done so far?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s had an urgent echo showing a large effusion with early signs of tamponade. Cardiology has reviewed and booked her for ultrasound-guided pericardiocentesis this afternoon. Consent is done.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: IV access?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Two good IVs—one 18G in the left AC and a 20G in the right forearm. Both patent. She’s on maintenance IV fluids—normal saline at 75 mL/hr.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Medications?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s had IV dexamethasone 8 mg this morning and regular paracetamol for discomfort. PRN midazolam is charted for the procedure. No anticoagulants on board. NKDA.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Observations?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: BP 102/68, HR 98, RR 22, SpO? 94% on 2 L, Temp 36.8. She’s alert and oriented but anxious. ECG shows low voltage QRS, no arrhythmias.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any support needs?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: English is her second language—Arabic is her first. She understands most things but prefers slow explanations. Her daughter is bilingual and has been helping. Interpreter has been requested for post-procedure education.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Got it. I’ll keep monitoring her obs closely and prep her for the drain.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if she deteriorates—especially signs of tamponade like hypotension or muffled heart sounds. All documentation is up to date, including consent, obs, and fluid balance.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over bed 8, Mr. Angelo Romano, 84 years old. He’s in for a TAVI via left subclavian access, scheduled for tomorrow morning. He’s now developed a new arrhythmia—I’ve notified the medical team.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay—what kind of arrhythmia?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He went into new-onset atrial fibrillation about an hour ago—irregularly irregular rhythm, HR peaked at 130. He’s asymptomatic but more confused than usual. No chest pain or syncope. ECG has been done and uploaded.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: What’s been done so far?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: The cardiology registrar has been notified and is reviewing. We’ve done a full set of bloods including U&Es, magnesium, and troponin. He’s on telemetry and we’re monitoring closely. No rate control started yet—awaiting medical orders.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: What’s his baseline?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Normally in sinus rhythm. He’s got known aortic stenosis and mild cognitive impairment. He’s also incontinent of urine—currently in pads. No IDC.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: IV access?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Two good IVs—18G in the right forearm and 20G in the left hand. Maintenance fluids running at 75 mL/hr. He’s fasting from midnight for the procedure.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Medications?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Regular meds include frusemide, aspirin, and atorvastatin. No anticoagulants yet—this will likely be reviewed post-TAVI. PRN paracetamol and haloperidol are charted. No known allergies.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any support needs?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: English is his second language—Italian is his first. Interpreter is booked for tomorrow. His daughter is his next of kin and has been very involved. He’s quite anxious and confused, especially with the new arrhythmia.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Got it. I’ll keep monitoring his rhythm and wait for the plan from cardiology.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if his condition worsens—especially if he becomes hypotensive or more confused. All documentation is up to date, including ECG, fluid balance, and neuro obs.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over bed 3, Mr. David Lee, 79 years old. He had a permanent pacemaker inserted this morning for complete heart block. Post-procedure, he developed a right-sided pneumothorax—a chest drain was inserted about an hour ago.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay—how is he now?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s more short of breath and becoming increasingly agitated. His oxygen requirement has gone up—now on 4 L via nasal prongs to maintain sats around 92%. BP is 98/60, HR is 62 (paced), RR 26, Temp 37.2. I’ve escalated to the medical registrar—awaiting review.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: How’s the drain functioning?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Swinging but minimal drainage so far. No signs of tension, but I’m concerned about his increased work of breathing and agitation. ECG shows paced rhythm, no acute changes.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any other issues?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes—he’s acutely incontinent of urine and hasn’t voided since the procedure. Abdomen is mildly distended. I’ve requested an IDC insertion—awaiting medical clearance due to the recent pacing procedure.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: IV access?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: One 18G in the left forearm—patent. He’s on maintenance fluids and has had IV paracetamol for discomfort. No antibiotics charted yet. NKDA.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any support needs?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: English is his first language. He’s usually independent but is now confused and distressed. Family has been notified and are on their way in.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Got it. I’ll keep monitoring his respiratory status and follow up on the IDC and medical review.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks. Please escalate if his condition worsens—especially if his sats drop further or he becomes more confused. All documentation is up to date, including drain chart, fluid balance, and neuro obs.

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi, this is Mrs. Joan Murphy, 73 years old. Joan, this is Liam, one of our physiotherapists. He’s here to help with your breathing and to assist with collecting a sputum sample.
[PHYSIO]: Hi Joan, nice to meet you. I’ll be working with you today to help clear your chest and get a sample if we can. How are you feeling?
[PATIENT]: Still a bit chesty and tired. I’ve been coughing but not bringing much up.
[NURSE]: Joan came in last night with an acute exacerbation of COPD—increased SOB, wheeze, and a productive cough. She’s now on IV ceftriaxone and hydrocortisone, and we’re trying to get a sputum sample for culture before the next dose.
[PHYSIO]: Okay, has she been able to expectorate anything yet?
[NURSE]: Not yet—she’s coughing but not clearing much. She’s on salbutamol and ipratropium nebs Q4H, and we’ve just given her a neb about 20 minutes ago to help loosen things up.
[PHYSIO]: Great, that should help. I’ll do some chest physio and see if we can get a sample.
[NURSE]: She’s on 2 L nasal prongs, target sats 88–92%. Her Q-ADDS score is 4, so she’s on 2-hourly observations. RR is 22, sats 91%, HR 96, BP 134/78, Temp 37.4. She’s also on a respiratory chart—we’re tracking sputum colour and volume, and she’s on a fluid balance chart due to poor oral intake.
[PHYSIO]: Understood. Joan, I’ll help you with some breathing techniques and gentle percussion. If you feel the urge to cough anything up, we’ll collect it in a sterile pot.
[PATIENT]: Okay, I’ll try.
[NURSE]: Thanks, Liam. Let me know if you’re able to get a sample or if she needs a second neb beforehand. Everything’s documented in the chart, and the pathology slip is ready.

example.text:
[WARD NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Peter Samuels, 69 years old. He’s being transferred to CCU with acute decompensated heart failure. Peter, this is Nurse Jess from the coronary care unit, and Dr. Patel, who’s overseeing your care.
[CCU NURSE]: Hi Peter, I’ll be looking after you in CCU. We’ll get you settled in and keep a close eye on your breathing and heart.
[PATIENT]: Thank you. I’m still feeling short of breath.
[WARD NURSE]: He came in yesterday with worsening dyspnoea, orthopnoea, and peripheral oedema. Chest X-ray showed pulmonary congestion. He’s been started on IV frusemide 40 mg BD, and a GTN infusion was commenced this morning for ongoing hypertension and chest tightness.
[DOCTOR]: We’re titrating the GTN to manage his preload and afterload. He’s also on oxygen via nasal prongs at 4 L/min, aiming for sats above 92%. We’ll review the need for non-invasive ventilation if he doesn’t improve.
[CCU NURSE]: What’s his current status?
[WARD NURSE]: He’s still dyspnoeic at rest. Q-ADDS score is 6—due to increased RR (28), borderline BP (98/60), and oxygen requirement. He’s on hourly observations. HR is 104, Temp 36.8, SpO? 93% on 4 L.
[CCU NURSE]: IV access?
[WARD NURSE]: Two good IVs—18G in the right AC and 20G in the left forearm. GTN is running via pump on the right side. He’s also on a strict fluid balance chart—he’s positive 1.2 L over the last 24 hours. Daily weights are being recorded.
[CCU NURSE]: Any other meds or comorbidities?
[WARD NURSE]: He’s on carvedilol, spironolactone, and atorvastatin. No known allergies. History of ischaemic cardiomyopathy, EF 25%, and CKD stage 3.
[PATIENT]: I’ve been feeling more tired and dizzy today.
[DOCTOR]: That’s why we’re moving you to CCU, Peter—to monitor you more closely and adjust your treatment as needed.
[CCU NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll continue hourly Q-ADDS, monitor the GTN infusion, and keep a close eye on his fluid status and oxygen needs.
[WARD NURSE]: Perfect. All documentation is up to date—Q-ADDS, fluid balance, and medication chart. Let me know if you need anything else.

pred_spans.quote: He’s being transferred to CCU with acute decompensated heart failure

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Ms. Lily Harper, 24 years old. Lily, this is Nurse Tessa, who’ll be looking after you this afternoon.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Lily, nice to meet you. I’ll be checking in on you regularly and helping with your care today.
[PATIENT]: Hi. Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Lily was admitted yesterday with bradycardia secondary to an eating disorder—her HR dropped to 38 bpm overnight. She’s now in CCU for cardiac monitoring. She’s alert and oriented but fatigued and intermittently dizzy.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: What’s her current status?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: HR is sitting around 42–45 bpm, sinus bradycardia on telemetry. BP is 92/58, RR 16, SpO? 98% on room air, Temp 36.2. She’s on Q-ADDS—scoring 5 due to HR and low-normal BP, so we’re doing hourly observations.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any IV access?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes—20G in the left forearm, patent. No IV fluids running currently, but we’ve kept the line in for access if needed.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Medications?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s on thiamine and multivitamins orally, and PRN lorazepam for anxiety. No cardiac meds charted at this stage. No known allergies.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: How’s her intake?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: We’ve started a strict food and fluid chart. Dietitian has reviewed and started a re-feeding plan—small, frequent meals. She’s eating slowly but has managed about 50% of her breakfast and lunch today. We’re monitoring for refeeding syndrome—daily bloods are being done.
[PATIENT]: I’m trying to eat, but it’s hard.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: That’s okay, Lily. We’ll support you through it. Just let me know if you feel unwell or overwhelmed.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s also on daily ECGs and electrolyte monitoring. Psych team has been consulted and will review again tomorrow. She’s been cooperative but very anxious.
[DOCTOR]: (enters briefly) Just confirming—Lily is for continued cardiac monitoring and nutritional support. Please escalate if HR drops below 35 or if she becomes symptomatic.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Got it. I’ll continue Q-ADDS, monitor intake, and keep an eye on her cardiac rhythm and electrolytes.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks. All documentation is up to date—Q-ADDS, food chart, and med chart.

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Daniel Jordan, 31 years old. Daniel, this is Alicia, one of our pharmacists. She’s here to talk to you about your new medication.
[PHARMACIST]: Hi Daniel, nice to meet you. I understand you’ve just been diagnosed with epilepsy.
[PATIENT]: Yeah… it’s a bit of a shock. I had a seizure yesterday, and they said it was my first one.
[NURSE]: He had a generalised tonic-clonic seizure yesterday morning. CT and EEG are pending, but neurology has started him on levetiracetam 500 mg BD. No IV access now—he’s on oral meds only. No known allergies.
[PHARMACIST]: Thanks. Daniel, I’ll go through how to take your medication, what side effects to watch for, and how to manage your day-to-day safely. Have you had a chance to read the medication leaflet?
[PATIENT]: Not yet. I’m still trying to take it all in.
[PHARMACIST]: That’s okay—we’ll take it step by step. Levetiracetam is taken twice a day, about 12 hours apart. It’s important not to miss doses. Some people feel a bit tired or moody when they first start, but that usually settles. If you feel very low or notice any big changes in mood, let us know straight away.
[NURSE]: He’s also on a food and fluid chart while we monitor his intake—he’s been a bit nauseous since yesterday but is improving.
[PHARMACIST]: Good to know. Daniel, you’ll also need to avoid driving for now—by law, you need to be seizure-free for a certain period before you can drive again. We’ll give you written information about that too.
[PATIENT]: Okay. I didn’t realise that.
[PHARMACIST]: Totally understandable. I’ll leave you with a medication info sheet and come back later to check if you have any questions. We’ll also make sure your GP and community pharmacy are updated when you’re discharged.
[NURSE]: Thanks, Alicia. I’ll keep monitoring his neuro obs and ensure he’s tolerating the meds. Daniel, just press the call bell if you feel unwell or have any questions.
[PATIENT]: Thanks both. I appreciate it.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning. Hi Jane, I’m Sam, the day nurse. I’ll just get handover from Alex, then check in with you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi Sam. This is Jane Morgan in bed 4. Jane, could you confirm your full name for us?
[PATIENT]: Jane Morgan.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Jane.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Jane is 24, under Dr Tilney, admitted with acute renal failure. There have been No changes overnight. All observations have remained stable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, Any concerns with pain or nausea?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No, she’s comfortable and denies nausea.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s on the last dose of her IV antibiotics today. The Plan is discharge her home tomorrow, and switching to oral antibiotics.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. And follow-up arranged?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes there's an outpatient appointment with Dr Diani, which has been organized.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Perfect.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Jane, how are you feeling this morning?
[PATIENT]: I’m okay, just keen to go home.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hopefully tomorrow, once we switch you to tablets. I’ll keep an eye on your obs and your last IV antibiotics.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything for Jane from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Alex. Jane, press your call bell if you need anything. I’ll be back shortly to check your observations and your IV.
[PATIENT]: Thank you.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Wendell. This is Sam, the incoming nurse for day shift. We’ll do a quick bedside handover if that’s okay.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi, Wendell. I’ll just check your ID band while Jack talks us through things.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Bed 3, is Wendell Mario Fleming, who is 41 years old, under Dr. Smith.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He came in with liver failure for investigation, and has a background of type 2 diabetes.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Are his blood sugars in range?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, He’s still for bloods, and for a liver biopsy. CT and MRI are to be arranged as part of the plan.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Do you think they will get done today? if they are not too busy.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Should do, He’s a bit jaundice and He has been vomiting during my shift; I gave him some antiemetics with good effect.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: How are you feeling now, Wendell?
[PATIENT]: Better than before. The nausea settled after the medication you gave me.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He was seen by the team today. They started IV fluids, running at 100 mls per hour.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: When was the cannula put in? or Any issues with the cannula?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: It was put in yesterday, He’s very difficult to cannulate, but the current line is patent and secure.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, I’ll keep a close eye on it.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: His obs have all been stable, and he’s self-caring and ambulant.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. Wendell, if you feel nauseated again or dizzy when you’re up and about, please press the call bell.
[PATIENT]: Will do.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll follow up the bloods, check with radiology regarding CT/MRI timing, continue IV fluids at 100 mls/hr, monitor for nausea, and keep observing his vitals.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Wendell, anything you want to add before I head off?
[PATIENT]: No, that’s all. Thanks.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Jack. I’ll be back shortly, Wendell.

preds.label: RECOMMENDATION

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, Ken. I’m Alex, the day nurse. I’ll just get handover from Maya, then we’ll check in with you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi Alex. This is Bed 3, Ken Harris, he is 71 years old, under Dr Gregor.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Ken, could you confirm your full name for me?
[PATIENT]: Ken Harris.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you. I’ve checked your ID band as well. The cannular looks like it needs changed it has been in for 3 days.  

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Ken came in with an arrhythmia. He had chest pain this morning an ECG was done and reviewed by the team. He was given anginine and morphine for the pain.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Ken, how’s the chest pain now? what is it out of 10? 10 being really bad.
[PATIENT]: Its about a 2, It’s eased off a lot. Just a bit uncomfortable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, we’ll keep an eye on it. Let me know if it gets any worse. 

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s still tachycardic at 120. Blood pressure has been within normal range for him. He’s scoring a QADDS of 3 for the tachycardia. He’s otherwise stable and for monitoring.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: what's his normal blood pressure? Does he have a history of atrial fibrillation?

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: His BP is normally 90/40. This is a new rhythm problem. New meds have been ordered in the med chart by the team after they reviewed the ECG. We're to continue pulse checks for a full minute with each set of obs.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: what time is the echo booked for?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Sometime this afternoon there is no exact time yet.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: okay, i'll chase it up and see if we can get it done today.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Ken, we’re waiting for your heart ultrasound this afternoon. We’ll keep checking your pulse and rhythm and let you know as soon as we have a time for the echo. If the chest pain worsens or you feel dizzy or short of breath, press your call bell straight away.
[PATIENT]: Okay, thanks.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Anything you need before I head off, Ken?
[PATIENT]: I’m fine for now.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Maya. I'll be back Ken to do some obs, soon.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi, Thuy. I’m Sam, I’ll be looking after you today. I’m just getting handover from Alex who’s finishing night shift, is that okay?
[PATIENT]: Sure.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Thuy. So, bed 8, is Thuy Leu, she is 29 years old, under Dr. Greger.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Thuy—could you please confirm your name for me?
[PATIENT]: Thuy Leu.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you. I’ll confirm your date of birth on the chart in a moment.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thuy came in with chest pain and was found to have blood clots in her lungs.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: What is the current plan from the team?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s still waiting for the doctors to review; they said they’ll be back later today to outline the plan.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, we’ll keep an eye out for them and follow up if needed.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s self-caring and ambulant.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thuy, please ring the bell if you feel dizzy or the pain ramps up before you walk anywhere.
[PATIENT]: Okay, I will.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Her observations have all been normal.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thuy, how’s your chest pain right now? what is it out of 10? 10 being really sore.
[PATIENT]: It’s there but manageable probably a 3.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: she’s had regular paracetamol and Endone as needed.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll check when the time when the next dose is due and reassess after I've done the obs.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Anything else that I need to chase?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: We are just waiting for the medical review and plan.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Alex.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thuy, is there anything you need before we go?
[PATIENT]: I’m okay for now, thanks.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Perfect. I’ll be back shortly to recheck your observations and pain and to touch base about the doctors’ review.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Scott. I’m Alex, I’ll be looking after you today. I’m just getting bedside handover from Mia, is that okay?
[PATIENT]: Sure.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll just check your ID band. Iv Cannula and heparin infusion, Thank you.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: This is Scott Rogers, 66 years old, In Bed 2 and is under Dr Dalianis. He came in with chest pain and coronary artery narrowing. He’s for a procedure later today.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Is he prepped?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes—pre‑op checklist is completed and filed at the front of the chart. An ECG has been done and looks normal. He’s in a gown and ready to go.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Fasting status?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Fasted from midnight for the procedure.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: And the planned procedure?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Depending on the blockage, they may do a stent or balloon angioplasty; CABG is also on the consent. The consent form is in the chart.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Observations?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: All observations are stable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great, we’ll keep you fasted and ready, Scott, and we’ll send you when they call for you.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Scott, do you need anything for comfort right now?
[PATIENT]: I’m okay, thanks.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: All right. I’ll keep an eye on your observations and paperwork. Mia, anything else?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s all for him.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Mia. Scott, press the call bell if you need us. I’ll be back shortly.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Good morning Vera. This is Samantha who’ll be looking after you now. We’ll do a quick bedside handover if that’s okay.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Vera, I’m Samantha taking over from Madeline. We’ll talk through your care with you here.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: This is Vera Abbott, 93 years old, under Dr Liu. She presented with chest pain.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Hi Vera, can you tell me your name, please?
[PATIENT]: Vera Abbott.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you, Vera. I’ll keep the call bell by your hand so you can reach it easily.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She has a history of stroke, prior chest pain episodes, cataracts, asthma, and glaucoma. She’s almost blind and needs assistance with ADLs.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: We’ll make sure you have help with moving around, meals, and personal care, Vera.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Today she’s had three nitro-glycerine sprays with no effect. I have done an ECG and given some Morphine, so she is now pain free. She’s on continuous monitoring.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Vera, are you comfortable at the moment?
[PATIENT]: I’m okay sitting here.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: All observations have been within normal range for her.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. I’ll keep reassessing your pain and monitoring closely. If the pain changes, please press the bell and we’ll let Dr Liu know as needed.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything I needed to tell you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Vera, is there anything you need right now before we finish?
[PATIENT]: No. Thank you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. I’ll be back to check on you shortly.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Mr Meyer. I’m the day nurse, Priya. I’ll just get handover from Tom who’s been looking after you overnight, if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi Priya. This is a new admission in Room 5, Bed 3: Mr Steve Richard Meyer, 71, under Dr Dalianis.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Mr Meyer, can I quickly confirm your identity on the wristband? And what name do you prefer to be called?
[PATIENT]: Richard is fine, thanks.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Perfect, thank you.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Richard was admitted with multiple cardiac issues. He’s not for surgery yet the team want some weight lost first before considering an operation. Observations have been stable on my shift.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, Any chest pain, shortness of breath, or dizziness overnight?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: None reported. Comfortable at rest, and seems settled.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s on a food chart and I have made a referral to the dietitian. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great—I’ll follow up dietetics for a time today.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He needs prompting with ADLs and benefits from reminders and some assistance with personal cares and meal setup.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: let us know when you want a shower and when you meal has arrived ring the buzzer. 

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Richard’s wife passed two months ago. He’s understandably low in mood. I recommend a pastoral care referral for grief support.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Richard, would you be okay for us to arrange someone from pastoral care or someone to talk with about support?
[PATIENT]: Yes, I’d appreciate that.
[INCOMING_NURSE]:I’ll place that referral this morning.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any lines or drains, special precautions, or allergies we should note?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No special lines or drains noted, and no new issues flagged on admission paperwork. Primary team is Cardiology under Dr Dalianis.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: So the  Plan for today is to continue routine obs, maintain food chart, follow up dietitian review, prompt and assist with ADLs, and place pastoral care referral. I’ll also update the team if there are any changes.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s all I can tell you for now.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Richard, is there anything you need right now before Tom heads off?
[PATIENT]: Maybe some help getting washed later and a cup of tea when I’m allowed.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Absolutely—we’ll help you freshen up after breakfast and I’ll check what drinks are okay with your diet plan. I’ll be back shortly.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Martin. I’m Priya, I’ll be looking after you today. I’m just getting handover from Alex who’s been on nights, is that okay?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Martin. We’ll keep this brief. This is Bed 4, Martin Cavedon, 73, under Dr. Sanchez.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Martin, could you tell us your full name and age, please?
[PATIENT]: Martin Cavedon, I’m 73.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Do you have any medication allergies?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: There is nothing documented in the chart.
[PATIENT]: No, none that I know of.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Martin came in with chest pain. He has a long history of heart problems, asthma, and GORD.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. Any chest pain at the moment, Martin?
[PATIENT]: No, it’s settled now.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Earlier he reported chest pain; he was given two Anginine with good effect, then a dose of morphine. He’s stable now and was monitored accordingly. [INCOMING_NURSE]:  Are observations up to date?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, all obs are charted with a QADDS of zero. ECG was taken as well no new changes.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Was there any Blood taken to check the troponin level?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, Blood results have just arrived in the system and are pending medical review. Please call the doctor to review them.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll page Dr. Sanchez’s team after we finish here.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: The plans it that he’s for a carotid ultrasound, this needs to be arranged, and an echocardiogram at some stage.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Martin, if the chest pain comes back, please press your call bell straight away.
[PATIENT]: I will, thanks.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Anything you need before we go, water or to adjust the bed?
[PATIENT]: I’m fine, thank you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Alex. I’ll get onto the doctors about the bloods and start organising the scans.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning. I’ll take over from here—shall we do a bedside handover?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, thanks. Hi, Mr Mendes—Ranjiv—this is Priya, she’ll be looking after you now.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi, Ranjiv. Can you confirm your full name for me?
[PATIENT]: Ranjiv Mendes.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you. Your IV cannula was put in today And I’ve checked your ID band—details match. We’ll talk through your care now.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Bed 8, Ranjiv Mendes, 77 years old. He’s a new admission—arrived about an hour ago with arrhythmia and chest pain. He also reported nausea and extreme tiredness on arrival.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He was given an antiemetic with good effect—the nausea has settled. We’ve taken bloods and he’s had an echocardiogram; we’re awaiting results for the team to review. Otherwise, his observations are stable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. Ranjiv, how are you feeling right now?
[PATIENT]: Tired, but the nausea’s much better.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good to hear. Any new symptoms, please let me know straight away.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Anything else outstanding?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s all for him at the moment—just monitoring and waiting on results.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Perfect. I’ll continue regular obs, keep you comfortable, and I’ll update you once the results are back. If your chest pain or palpitations return, please press the call bell.
[PATIENT]: Okay.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Do you need anything before we go?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m fine, thanks.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Ranjiv. I’ll head off. Priya’s got you now.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll be back shortly to re-check your observations.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Raquel, I’m the day nurse coming on. I’m just going to get handover from my colleague, is that okay?
[PATIENT]: Yes, that’s fine.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Raquel. So, this is Raquel Suarez Cayetano in Bed 1, under Dr. Mills. She’s a 62-year-old new admission, arrived about three hours ago.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Raquel, we will include you in the handover as we go.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Her presenting complaints are chest pain, tiredness, dizziness, and low mood/depression. She also reports pain every time she eats, though it doesn’t seem clearly related to her digestion. She’s here for further investigation.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. what is her past history?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Type 2 diabetes and obesity noted. No other history has been provided yet.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Are the Allergies documented?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No not yet, we still need to confirm and chart them.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Raquel, do you have any medication or food allergies that you’re aware of?
[PATIENT]: Not that I know of.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you. We will double-check with you again soon.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Has there been any initial investigations or treatments started?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s admitted for further investigation; ED notes indicate the symptom set as above. No additional details yet from medical team—awaiting plan from Dr. Mills’ team.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Raquel, are you having any chest pain right now?
[PATIENT]: It comes and goes. It’s not too bad at the moment.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you. We’ll keep checking in with you but let us know if you do have any pain.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s all I have at this stage for Raquel—new admission, three hours in, awaiting further workup.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Raquel, we’ll continue regular observations, keep you comfortable, and I’ll follow up with Dr. Mills’ team about the plan. Is there anything you need right now?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m okay. Thank you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. Call bell is within reach—please buzz if the chest pain worsens or you feel more dizzy.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Maria. We’re just going to do your bedside handover with the day nurse now.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Maria, I’ll be looking after you today. Could you confirm your full name for me?
[PATIENT]: Maria Clemens.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: This is Maria, 79 years old, under Dr. Chanson. She came in with shortness of breath on exertion.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Goals of care: NFR not for resus and not for MET, as per the chart.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay is that filed in her chart?

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes. She has multiple allergies (documented on the chart and band). She’s on regular inhaler puffers and a high dose of prednisolone.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s having daily random capillary BGLs.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, I’ll make sure the BGL is checked today and meds given per chart.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Mobility-wise, she walks independently with a wheely walker.
[PATIENT]: Yes, I manage fine with it.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s awaiting team review and an OT review; physio is ongoing.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Observations have been stable. Noted nail changes on assessment. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Maria, how’s your breathing right now — any shortness of breath at rest?
[PATIENT]: It’s okay while I’m sitting. Worse when I walk.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll keep an eye on that and pace activities.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: The plan is to continue regular puffers and prednisolone, daily random BGLs, await medical team and OT reviews, continue physio, mobilise with the wheely walker as tolerated.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll ensure allergy precautions are in place and the call bell is within reach.
[PATIENT]: Thank you.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Anything else you need before we finish, Maria?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m fine.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me. Thanks.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Good Morning. Let's do bedside handover for Bed 3.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi Kelly, this is Sam, the incoming nurse who'll be looking after you today.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Kelly. Is it okay if we do handover at the bedside?
[PATIENT]: Sure.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Could you please confirm your full name and date of birth?
[PATIENT]: Kelly Diana Clarkson. 12 Jan 1990
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you. And any allergies?
[PATIENT]: Pollen — I get hayfever.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Kelly is 36 years old, and is under Dr. Mills. She was admitted with query asthma for further investigation.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Her past history includes bronchitis, and she’s recently had influenza.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s allergic to pollens, as she mentioned.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s currently on oral antibiotics.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s ambulant, self-caring, and on a general diet.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Any specific tests or times booked yet?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Not yet — we are waiting further directions from Dr. Mills’ team.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Kelly, how are you feeling right now? Any concerns you want me to know about?
[PATIENT]: I’m okay, just a bit chesty from the recent flu.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll keep an eye on your breathing and check your medication chart for the antibiotics. You’re fine to continue with the general diet.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Kelly, press the call bell if you need anything. I’ll be back shortly to do your observations and touch base about the plan for today.
[PATIENT]: Thanks.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi Rhonda, this is Sam, the day nurse who’ll be looking after you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Rhonda, nice to meet you. We’ll just do a quick bedside handover together.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Rhonda, could you please tell us your full name and date of birth?
[PATIENT]: I’m Rhonda McKenzie. Date of birth is the 12th of May.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Rhonda. I’ll just check your wristband… great, details match your IV cannula is due to be changed today.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: So, this is Rhonda McKenzie, 24 years old, admitted for investigation of breathing disorders with an overnight sleep study.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: History-wise, she reports new snoring noted by her boyfriend and feeling tired despite getting about nine hours of sleep.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s otherwise well today. No concerns raised this shift.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. Has a time been set for the sleep study?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Not yet. She’ll need preparation for the sleep study tonight; the sleep lab will let us know the time and come to set up.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: We will run through the prep checklist this afternoon once they call.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Rhonda, any allergies we should know about?
[PATIENT]: No, I don’t have any.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any shortness of breath or chest discomfort right now?
[PATIENT]: No, I feel okay.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: The plan for today is routine care, await the sleep lab timing, and complete sleep-study preparation this evening.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Sounds good. Rhonda, if you need anything before they come, use the call bell. I’ll check in again shortly.
[PATIENT]: Thanks.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Christina. I’m the day nurse, Sam. I’ll just get handover from Taylor here at your bedside if that’s okay.
[PATIENT]: That’s fine.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Christina. Bed 5, Christina Davis, who is 29 years old, under Dr. Mills. She originally presented with vomiting and was diagnosed with pneumonia.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s pregnant, and she mentioned she has a 3-year-old daughter. She’s been coughing, particularly after talking.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Right.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s on oral antibiotics. Observations have been stable throughout my shift, with a QADDs of zero.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any other issues overnight? 
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No, nothing else to note.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Christina, how are you feeling now? Okay to speak or would you prefer short questions?
[PATIENT]: Talking makes me cough more.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Understood. Any nausea at the moment?
[PATIENT]: No, just the cough.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Taylor, any pending tests or consults?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: None pending at the moment.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: The plan for the morning is to continue oral antibiotics as charted, keep observations going, minimize long conversations to reduce cough triggers, and call us if you feel more short of breath or the cough worsens.
[PATIENT]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: I’ve documented the stable obs and that she’s tolerating care.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Christina, I’ll come back shortly with your medications and to recheck your observations. Is the call bell is within reach?
[PATIENT]: Yes.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Taylor. Have a good rest.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks. Bye, Christina.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Natalia, I’m Sam, I’ll be looking after you today. I’m just getting handover from Mia, is that okay?
[PATIENT]: Sure.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Natalia. So, Bed 1 is Natalia Torres, who is 45yrs, under Dr. Cox. Diagnosis and her full history are in the chart.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s still febrile, temps up to 39.3, ongoing for almost two weeks. Antipyretics have been given, but the fever’s persisted.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. Natalia, are you feeling shivery or headachy right now?
[PATIENT]: I'm just hot and tired.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s been coughing up small amounts of blood and having some difficulty breathing.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Natalia, has the coughing or breathlessness changed overnight?
[PATIENT]: No, about the same. Just little streaks when I cough.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Otherwise she’s self-caring and ambulant. No other changes—she’s still the same as yesterday.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. Any new meds or interventions overnight?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No new orders overnight aside from regular antipyretics as charted.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Natalia, are you comfortable walking to the bathroom yourself, or would you like us to walk with you?
[PATIENT]: I can walk, but I’d like someone nearby because of the breathing.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: No problem, we’ll assist. Just ring me when you need to go to the toilet.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: What is the plan for Natalia?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Continue antipyretics as ordered, monitor fever and respiratory status. Escalate to the medical team if the haemoptysis increases or her breathing becomes worse.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll keep close eye on observations and let Dr. Cox’s team know of any changes.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Natalia, is there anything you need right now—water, fan, or a cool cloth?
[PATIENT]: A cool cloth would be nice.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll bring that straight in. Thanks, Mia.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Good Morning. This is Bed 5, Sandra Murdock.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Sandra, I’m the incoming nurse. We’ll just do a quick bedside handover with you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Sandra, could you confirm your full name for us?
[PATIENT]: Sandra Murdock.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Sandra. 

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Sandra is 48 years old, under Dr. Cox. She was admitted with a lung cyst.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She had a chest X-ray yesterday and a lung ultrasound. She had a lung biopsy today.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any immediate issues post-biopsy?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No immediate concerns so far. She seems comfortable and resting.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: The surgeons still need to review her today to decide on whether she need to have surgery.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: If they proceed, she needs to be nil by mouth tonight.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, I’ll place NBM orders/signage for tonight if its confirmed.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Do you have Pain, or feeling more breathlessness, or anything we can get you now, Sandra?
[PATIENT]: I’m comfortable, thanks.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: I think I have covered everything. She seems okay and is resting.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll keep an eye out for the surgical team and any updates from biopsy. Sandra, buzz if you need anything.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Good Morning. This is Pamela Harris Lee in bed 6. Pamela, this is Alex, the day nurse taking over from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Pamela, nice to meet you. Is it okay if we do your bedside handover together?
[PATIENT]: Sure.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Pamela is 51 years old, admitted with an exacerbation of COPD. She’s a smoker and came in today with increased shortness of breath.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I am just going to check your arm band, Thanks. Pamela, can you confirm your full name for me?
[PATIENT]: Pamela Harris Lee.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you. Any medication allergies?
[PATIENT]: No allergies that I know of.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s much the same as she was on arrival. She’s on her regular inhalers and nebulisers, and she’s pretty stable at the moment.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any changes in observations or need for escalation?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No changes. Observations are stable and there are no new concerns during my shift.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Is oxygen required?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Not at the moment she is maintaining her satuarations at 98% on room air with nebs/inhalers as charted.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Pamela, how are you feeling right now?
[PATIENT]: Still a bit short of breath, but better after the nebs.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. I’ll make sure your inhalers and nebulisers are on time, and check in regularly with you let me know if you feel more short of breath.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: The plan for today is to continue regular puffers and nebs as charted, and  monitor her respiratory status and observations. She’s currently stable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll review inhaler technique later and make sure she's comfortable. Pamela, press your call bell if your breathing worsens or you need anything.
[PATIENT]: Will do, thank you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: All right, that’s everything from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll take it from here.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Morning, Jeffrey. This is the day nurse taking over. We’ll do a quick bedside handover.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: To confirm, could you tell me your full name, please?
[PATIENT]: Jeffrey Castro.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you, Jeffrey. I’ll just check your wristband… all good. Bed 6, under Dr. Hudgens, I'll just check your IV mediations with the order.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: So, this is bed 6, Jeffrey Castro, 73 years old, under Dr. Hudgens. He came in with COPD. He’s still the same as yesterday—no changes overnight—and observations are all stable. He has been started on IV fluids as he seems a bit dehydrated. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any issues with shortness of breath, chest pain, or new cough overnight?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No, there have been no complaints of pain and he is normally slightly short of breath so nothing new to report as there are no changes from his baseline.
[PATIENT]: I feel about the same.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. Any treatments or interventions pending this morning?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No new orders at the moment. Continue care as charted and keep monitoring.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. We’ll continue routine obs and keep an eye on your breathing and comfort, Jeffrey. If anything changes and you become more breathless, or get chest pain, or you feel unwell—please press the call bell.
[PATIENT]: Will do.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Do you need anything before we finish handover, more water, your pillows adjusted, or help to the bathroom?
[PATIENT]: I’m fine for now, thanks.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: The call bell is within reach here on your right, Jeffrey.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll review your chart now and be back shortly to check in again. Thanks for the handover.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No worries. I’m off—have a good day.
[PATIENT]: Thank you.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Jeff. I’m handing over to Mia, who’ll be looking after you today.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Jeff, I’m Mia. Is it okay if we do your bedside handover now?
[PATIENT]: Sure.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Bed 1, Jeffrey Morgan Rossiter , he prefers Jeff, he is 76 years old, under Dr. Hudgens. He presented with pain; we’re investigating the source—cardiac, respiratory, or gastrointestinal.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Jeff, are you having any pain right now?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m comfortable at the moment.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s stable and has had no other pain noted since arrival.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. What’s planned today?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s for CT chest and abdomen to be arranged, echocardiogram, stress test, and lung function tests—all to be booked. He’s also still for bloods and ongoing monitoring.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. You have a bit on today Jeff,  I’ll chase up bookings and get the bloods done shortly, then continue observations.
[PATIENT]: Sounds good.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s all from me for Jeff.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Jeff, if you get any pain or feel unwell, please press the call bell. I’ll be back after I’ve arranged those tests.
[PATIENT]: Will do. Thank you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Jeff. Have a good day.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks for the handover.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]:Good Morning, Coco. I’m just handing over to Priya for day shift, is that okay?
[PATIENT]: Sure.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi, Coco. I’m Priya. We’ll do a quick bedside handover.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Great. This is bed three, Coco Constantino, 61 years old, under Dr. Hudgens. He came in with pneumonia and an allergic reaction to penicillin.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Coco, can you confirm your name for me?
[PATIENT]: Coco Constantino.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you. Any allergies?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes—penicillin. He was accidentally prescribed penicillin for the pneumonia and developed a rash, fever, and difficulty breathing afterward. Allergy is now documented.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Noted—penicillin allergy with rash, fever, breathing difficulty.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Respiratory-wise, he’s on his regular puffers with PRN nebulisers. He’s also on prednisolone; we’re doing random BGLs. He’s on oral antibiotics and an antihistamine.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I will do  BGL checks, and give oral ABs (non-penicillin), and antihistamine as ordered.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Today he’s afebrile. He’s on oxygen at 2 litres via nasal prongs. Sats are normal and all other obs are stable. He has a QADDS of 2 for breathing the doctors are aware.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Coco, how’s your breathing now?
[PATIENT]: Better than yesterday.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good to hear. Any itch or rash still bothering you?
[PATIENT]: A bit of itch, but it’s settling.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s self-caring and ambulant.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: The plan for today is to continue oxygen at 2 L and wean as tolerated, monitor sats and obs, continue puffers/PRN nebs, steroids with random BGLs, oral antibiotics and antihistamine. We’ll reinforce the penicillin allergy bracelet and chart.
[PATIENT]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Okay are you happy with the handover
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Coco, press the call bell if you feel short of breath or the rash worsens. I’ll be back to check your sugars and see if we can reduce the oxygen later.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Matthew. I’m taking over your care now. Is it okay if we do your bedside handover with Jack?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi Matthew, I’m just handing over to Evie for day shift.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Could you please confirm your full name and date of birth?
[PATIENT]: Matthew David Dung. Date of birth is 28 September 1967
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Matthew. Any medication allergies?
[PATIENT]: Not that I’m aware of.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: We’ll double-check your chart as well.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: This is Bed 4, Matthew David Dung, 63 years old, under Dr. McDonald.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He presented with headache, nausea, and pain on inhalation following a gas leakage exposure at home.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s on regular paracetamol for pain and has PRN anti‑emetics charted.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: All observations have remained stable, and there have been no other changes since admission so a QAADS of Zero.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Matthew, are you still feeling the headache and nausea this morning?
[PATIENT]: Yes, about the same. The breathing in still hurts a bit.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks for letting me know. I’ll make sure you’re due for your paracetamol and offer an anti‑emetic if you need it.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any IV lines or special equipment in use? 
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No, none. Routine monitoring only. He’s stable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. So the plan is continue regular paracetamol, anti‑emetics PRN, and ongoing obs?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, but we need to escalate to the doctors if the symptoms worsen, otherwise no new orders from Dr. McDonald.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Perfect.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Matthew, is there anything you need right now—water, comfort measures, a cool cloth?
[PATIENT]: Maybe an anti‑emetic soon, please.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Sure, I’ll bring that in shortly and recheck your obs.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Matthew. I’ll leave you with Evie now.
[PATIENT]: Thank you.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Oliver, I’m the incoming nurse. We’ll do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, is that okay?
[PATIENT]: Sure.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Oliver. This is Oliver Green in bed five, he is 41 years old, under Dr McDonald. He’s come in with asthma for investigation.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Oliver, could you confirm your full name for us?
[PATIENT]: Oliver Green.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you. Any allergies we should know about?
[PATIENT]: No, none that I’m aware of.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s a smoker. Observations have been stable today his QADDS is zero today. He’s just arrived on the ward, so the doctors haven’t reviewed him yet and I’m not sure of the plan at this stage.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. Are you comfortable right now—any shortness of breath or chest tightness?
[PATIENT]: I’m okay at the moment.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s ambulant and self-caring. No other complaints noted.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. I’ll keep monitoring your observations and we’ll touch base with Dr McDonald’s team when they come around. If you feel any worsening breathlessness or wheeze, press the call bell straight away.
[PATIENT]: Will do.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That's it from me
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Oliver, do you need anything before we go?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m fine, thanks.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Alright, I’ll be back to check on you shortly.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Neil. I’m Sam, I’ll be looking after you today. Is it okay if we do your handover at the bedside?
[PATIENT]: Sure.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Neil. Hi Sam. This is Bed 4, Neil Paganus, He is 39 years old.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Neil, can you tell me your full name, please?
[PATIENT]: Neil Paganus.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you. I'll  just check your medication charts and IV cannula to make sure they are up to date. 

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Neil came in with severe allergy symptoms and a history of asthma. He had difficulty breathing and was very chesty on arrival. He was febrile with a temperature of 38.8.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: We took blood cultures and gave paracetamol with good effect. The medical team has reviewed; Dr Tim was informed, and antibiotics have been changed as per their plan.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: So the Blood cultures are still pending?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: How’s your breathing now, Neil?
[PATIENT]: Better than before, still a bit tight but improving.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, we’ll keep a close eye on that.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s on a general diet, self-caring, and ambulant.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any other concerns overnight?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No acute events after paracetamol. He’s been comfortable and mobilizing independently.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. Any specific precautions?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Just routine observations, we are monitoring his temperature and respiratory status, and giving the antibiotics as charted.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Neil, we’ll keep checking your observations and let you know when any results come back. Please use the call bell if your breathing worsens or you feel unwell.
[PATIENT]: Will do, thanks.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks for the handover.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No worries. I’m off—call me if you need anything before I go.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: So, Mike is 48 years old, admitted for investigation of chest pain—query heartburn versus heart attack. He’s on regular nitrates as charted. Observations have been stable. He’s for repeat bloods tomorrow. An echocardiogram still needs to be arranged. Plan is to keep monitoring for now.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Just to confirm he's on regular nitrates, his obs are stable, and he needs repeat bloods tomorrow, an  echo needs to be organized, and we will continue monitoring him.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Nope that's everything.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: In bed 7 we have Linda Donald, 83 years old, under Dr Harrod.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Linda, I’m the incoming nurse my name is Brett. We’ll just do a quick bedside handover together, is that okay?
[PATIENT]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Linda came in for investigation due to memory problems and increasing confusion.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Have her observations been checked?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, obs are done and all stable, nothing remarkable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Has the medical team seen her yet?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Not yet.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: How is she getting around?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s ambulant with a wheely walker, with 1 to standby assist.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: We’ll make sure it’s within reach and help you as needed, don't get up on your own
[PATIENT]: Thank you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any diet orders?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She's on a soft diet which she is tolerating well, but needs help with setting up the tray table, and taking the lids off the cups. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay is there anything else that I need to know?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No, shes stable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: So, the plan is to continue regular observations, assist with mobility using the walker, help her with her meals and wait for the team to review her.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: I think I have covered everything.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Linda, do you need anything before we go?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m fine.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: We’ll be back shortly. Please use the call bell if you need help.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Good Morning. This is David Adams in bed 8, he is under Dr. Wu.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi David, I’m taking over your care now. We’ll just do a quick bedside handover.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: David, could you confirm your name for us please, and date of birth?
[PATIENT]: David Adams. 16 January 1984
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, David. Any allergies recorded?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: None recorded on the chart.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: David is 34, admitted with a head injury. He’s been having headaches and is photophobic.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]:  He’s on Endone and morphine for the pain, and is for a CT brain tomorrow, and depending on those results, they’re planning to do endoscopic brain surgery later this week.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay,  I’ll keep an eye on the schedule for CT.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s for daily bloods but he is a difficult stab, you may need to get the phlebotomist to do them, he's on neuro obs QID as per orders.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Have the bloods been taken today? 
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No, not yet, I'll ring the phlebotomist before I go home. His GCS has been 15 throughout my shift, and his observations have been stable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s pretty much self-caring and we’ve not noted any other issues.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: David, we’ll keep the lights a bit dim for your comfort with the photophobia and keep working on your pain relief. If your headache worsens or anything changes, please buzz.
[PATIENT]: Okay, thanks.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: So the plan is to continue Endone/morphine for pain as charted, QID neuro obs, daily bloods, CT brain tomorrow, and wait for the surgical plan based on results.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Anything you want to add, David?
[PATIENT]: No, that’s all good.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll be back shortly to do your next set of obs.

[PATIENT]: Sure, that’s fine.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Nick. This is the bedside handover for Room 2, Bed 1. Patient is Nick Smith, 45 years old, under Dr. Wu. He came in with a head injury.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Nick, I’m the day nurse. Could you confirm your full name for me?
[PATIENT]: Nick Smith.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you. ID band matches. Any allergies we should know about?
[PATIENT]: None that I know of.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Overnight he’s been alright, no other problems reported. No changes noted—he’s still the same as prior shift.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any new symptoms—headache getting worse, nausea, vomiting, confusion, vision changes?
[PATIENT]: No, nothing new. I feel about the same.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Neuro checks unchanged from earlier entries. No concerns raised overnight. Vitals stable as per obs chart.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any lines or drains we need to be aware of?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No new lines or devices. Usual monitoring only.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. Plan is to continue neuro observations as charted and escalate if there’s any change, and await Dr. Wu’s review?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Exactly. Call the team if there’s any neuro deterioration or if pain escalates.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Nick, your call bell is right here. Please press it if you notice worsening headache, feel sick, or anything doesn’t feel right.
[PATIENT]: Got it. Thanks.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Anything else you need before I head off?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m okay.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll check your chart and be back shortly to repeat your observations.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Esther. I’ll head off. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll be back shortly to check on you.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Miranda. This is the day nurse who’ll be looking after you now his name is Ben.

[PATIENT]: I’m fine, thanks.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Ross. I’m just here to get bedside handover from the night nurse, is that okay?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi Mark. This is Bed 3, Ross Garden, is 24 years old, and is under Dr. Fleming.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Ross, could you confirm your full name and date of birth? 
[PATIENT]: Ross Garden. 12 December 2002
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great, thank you. We’ll keep this brief.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Ross came in with a minor head injury after a car racing accident. He’s the same as yesterday with no new issues, we’re waiting for the doctors to do their rounds today. They can't be far away.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any changes overnight—vomiting, worse headache, confusion, or anything like that?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No, nothing new reported. He’s been stable and comfortable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. Ross, how are you feeling right now?
[PATIENT]: I’m okay. No changes.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good to hear. Do you need anything before we finish handover?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m fine.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: The Plan is to continue as we are and wait for the medical review on the morning round.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Got it. let us know if anything changes and you get a headache, feel nauseated or dizzy press the call bell straight away, Ross.
[PATIENT]: Will do.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll be back shortly to do your routine checks.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Morning, Stephen. I’m Priya, the day nurse. I’m just going to get handover from Alex, who’s been looking after you overnight.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi Priya. This is Stephen Jonathan Spencer in bed 6, under Dr. Liu.
[PATIENT]: Hi.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Stephen. We’ll chat through the plan and make sure you’re comfortable.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Stephen is 72 years old. He came in with fevers and tiredness. He’s visiting from Melbourne and is here to see his daughter and grandchildren—and became unwell.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: His past history includes a coronary artery bypass graft about three months ago. His observations have been stable overnight. He’s still for investigation at this stage.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: So there's been no acute issues overnight?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No, all stable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Stephen, how are you feeling now?
[PATIENT]: A bit tired, but okay. I Just want to know what’s going on.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: We’ll keep your observations going and wait for Dr. Liu’s team to review and plan the next tests. If you feel more feverish or unwell, press the call bell and let me know.
[PATIENT]: Will do.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Alex. Stephen, I’ll be back shortly to check you over again.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: good Morning, Mr. Keller. I’m Evie, I’ll be looking after you today. I’m just getting handover from Jack.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi Luke, we’re just doing your bedside handover.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Can you tell us your name?
[PATIENT]: I… I want to go home.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: That’s okay. I’ll just check your ID band… Luke Keller, 74, under Dr. Lee. Thanks.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: So, Bed 1, Luke Keller, who is 74 years old, under Dr. Lee. Admitted with Alzheimer’s disease. His observations are stable.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s very confused and may become aggressive at times. We need to get security to help us as he punches and kicks at times
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, so security know that we will contact them if he gets too aggressive? .
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes. he needs a hosit to transer with  2–3 people as he is heavy. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: how much does he weigh?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s 150 kg and is doubly incontinent of urine and feces and has a pad in situ.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He needs to be fed and must sit fully upright when eating, so he doesn't choke.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: His Tablets need to be crushed; he also needs a referral to Speech Pathology.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll do the SP referral for you if you like, I'll get the wardsman to help me sit him up.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s a high falls risk.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He needs regular pressure area care and is on a pressure-relieving mattress as he stays in bed most of the time.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: How often is he being turned? 
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Evry 2 hours Otherwise, he’s stable.

[PATIENT]: Where’s my wife?
[INCOMING_NURSE]: We’ll check on that for you, Luke. I’ll be back shortly to help you with breakfast and your morning care.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Is there anything else you need right now, Luke?
[PATIENT]: No… okay.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Jack. I’ll take it from here.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Gus. I’m Alex, the day nurse. I’ll just get handover from Mia and then we’ll check in with you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi Gus, I’m Mia from night shift. Is it okay if we do bedside handover with you?
[PATIENT]: Yes, that’s fine.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Great, thank you. Could you please confirm your full name and date of birth?
[PATIENT]: Gus Milano, and 12 May 1951.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Gus. And you’re in bed two under Dr. Lee. 

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: So, this is Gus, who is 73 years old, admitted today with depression on the background of cancer. He’s just arrived and is still waiting for a psychiatry review, pastoral care, and for Dr. Lee’s team to come by.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, so still needs a nursing admission and psych review. How have his observations been?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: All stable since arrival QADDS of 1 for HR. He’s tolerating diet and fluids without any issues.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any IV lines or special precautions?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No special supports needed at present. 4 Houry observations.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Medications all up to date on the chart?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes the Chart’s in the file; the team will write it up when they see him.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Gus, how are you feeling right now—any nausea, pain, or dizziness?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m okay physically.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks for letting us know. Are you feeling safe here? If you have any thoughts of harming yourself or feel very distressed, please tell us straight away so we can help.
[PATIENT]: I will, thank you.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: So the Plan for the morning is to continue routine obs, assist with meals as needed, and we’re awaiting psych, pastoral care, and the medical team review.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll keep an eye out for those teams and check back after rounds. Anything else outstanding?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Mia.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Gus, your observations look good. I’ll be back shortly—use the call bell if you need anything or if your mood dips and you want to talk.
[PATIENT]: Okay, thanks.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi there, Bill. This is Sam, the day nurse taking over from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Bill, I’m Sam. We’ll do a quick bedside handover. Please jump in if we miss anything.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Could you confirm your name for us, please?
[PATIENT]: Bill Jefferies.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Bill.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Bed three, Bill Jefferies, 63 years old, under Dr Lane. Admitted today with known cancer and a recent brain injury. I’ve completed his initial observations; he’s on hourly obs for another four hours, then four‑hourly observations after that.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: So hourly for four hours, then Q4H afterwards?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s right.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s now allowed to eat and drink. He’s wide awake and is less drowsy than he was earlier. The Main issue is pain — he’s currently complaining of pain and is due for analgesia now.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll give some pain relief as soon as we finish handover. Bill, where is it most sore?
[PATIENT]: My head, mostly.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, I’ll bring something for that right away.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s on ongoing IV fluids at 125 mL/hour. He’s started on oral antibiotics — next dose can be given after his lunch.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: IV at 125 mL/hr running, and oral antibiotics after lunch at 1330.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He remains under close monitoring. No bleeding noted from the head; dressing is clean, dry, and intact.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. I’ll keep an eye on the site and continue the neuro and vital sign observations as ordered.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Bill, you’re okay to have something to eat and drink now. Are you feeling up to some lunch and a sip of water?
[PATIENT]: I could try a little.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Perfect — I’ll sort your pain relief first, then we’ll get you comfortable with some food and fluids.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: So the plan is to continue Hourly obs for four hours then change them to Q4H, give analgesia now, maintain IV fluids at 125 mL/hr, 
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me, see you tommorrow
[PATIENT]: Thanks.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Bill. I’ll be right back with your pain medication.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Aaron, I’m Evie, I’ll be looking after you today. I’m just going to get bedside handover from Jack, if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Morning Aaron. This is Evie, she’s taking over from me now.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Can I quickly confirm your details? Could you tell me your full name, and I’ll check your ID band for your date of birth.
[PATIENT]: Aaron Kuipers.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Aaron. ID band matches the chart and date of birth is 15 July 1999

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: So, bed 5 is Aaron Kuipers, who is 37 years old, under Dr Ling. He’s just arrived with depression. He’s had multiple admissions this year for the same reason.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s here for a psychiatry review referral and for the doctors to review his medications. The psych referral’s requested but not done yet, and the medical team will review his meds on their round.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Observations are stable. That’s all from my side.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, thanks. No acute medical issues flagged, vitals stable, awaiting psych and medication review. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Aaron, I’ll be checking in with you regularly. If you need anything or start to feel worse, please press the call bell.
[PATIENT]: Okay, thanks.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Is there anything you need right now—food, water, or a blanket?
[PATIENT]: I’m okay for now.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: All right. I’ll make sure your obs are done as scheduled and keep you updated about the psych team and Dr Ling’s review.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Great. I’ll head off then. Thanks, Aaron.
[PATIENT]: Thanks.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Jerry, I’m Taylor, I’ll be looking after you today. I’m just going to get handover from Sam who’s been on the night shift, is that okay?
[PATIENT]: Sure.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Morning, Taylor. This is Jerry Reed.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Jerry.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Jerry is 45, under Dr. Harry. He has a history of congestive cardiac failure, IHT, hypertension, type 2 diabetes (diet controlled), and depression.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He came in with bilateral leg oedema. He has a right AV graft and is scheduled for haemodialysis tomorrow afternoon.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, he has a right AV graft in situ, and dialysis is tomorrow afternoon.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s on a 1.2-litre fluid restriction with daily weights. He’s on IV furosemide. We also need lying and standing blood pressures to be done this afternoon.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll do the blood pressure this afternoon. 
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s for the diabetic educator tomorrow at 1 pm, and there’s a family meeting booked for Thursday at 2:30 pm.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, diabetic educator tomorrow 1300, family meeting Thursday 1430.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Jerry’s been very demanding and at times aggressive with staff. We’ve been using clear communication and de-escalation; please approach with firm boundaries and escalate if safety is a concern.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks for the heads-up. Jerry, we want to make sure you feel heard and comfortable. If something’s not working for you, let us know and we’ll do our best within the plan we have.
[PATIENT]: Okay.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any pain or shortness of breath right now?
[PATIENT]: Just the legs feel heavy. No chest pain.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s consistent with earlier. No other acute issues noted on my shift.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. I’ll double-check your weight, input/output, and confirm your dialysis booking for tomorrow afternoon. I’ll also set reminders for the orthostatic BPs.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. That’s everything from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Sam. Jerry, I’ll be back shortly with your morning plan and to talk through the fluid restriction and what to expect today.
[PATIENT]: Thanks.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Andrew. I’m Sarah, I’ll be looking after you today. I’m just getting handover from Tom, the night nurse—does that sound okay?
[PATIENT]: Yes, that’s fine.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. Could you tell us your full name, please?
[PATIENT]: Andrew Hamond.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: This is Andrew Hamond, 81 years old, under Dr. Morris, room 1 bed 2. He came in with sepsis on the background of chronic renal failure secondary to hypertension. He’s on haemodialysis via a right arm AV fistula—thrill is good.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: so no needles in that arm, due to the fistula.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s still on IV antibiotics—vancomycin—and IV therapy. Normal saline is running at 83 mL per hour. He’s due for a vancomycin level tomorrow morning. We’re doing lying and standing blood pressures, daily weights, and strict fluid balance charting.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, so Vancomycin is ongoing, a vancomycin  level is due tomorrow morning, he has NS 83 mL/hr.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: His next dialysis is on the morning list tomorrow. Blood pressures remain low—systolic 80 to 90—so he’s still on IV fluids. The team plan is to give albumin if his blood pressure doesn’t improve tomorrow after dialysis.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Is there another bag of fluids written up after this one goes through? 
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, He spiked a temperature last night—38.4°C. We took blood cultures and gave paracetamol with good effect. He’s been afebrile today on my shift and otherwise all his obs are stable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll keep an eye out for the culture results and continue monitoring.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Andrew, how are you feeling right now—any fever or chills?
[PATIENT]: No, I feel okay. A bit tired.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks—we’ll keep your fluids going and check your blood pressures lying and standing. Please press the call bell if you feel dizzy or unwell.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Tom. I’ll review the med chart, confirm the vancomycin level time for the morning, and update the fluid balance and weight. Andrew, I’ll be back shortly to do your observations.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi both. This is room 1,the patient is Ian Ramsey, 40, under Dr. Morris.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Ian, could you confirm your full name for us? do you have any Allergies?
[PATIENT]: Ian Ramsey, only to bees.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, 

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Ian came in yesterday with severe lower back pain secondary to a urinary obstruction, he has  a long history of kidney problems. He’s still under investigation. The CT showed an obstruction of the ureters and the team are planning to put a stent in. He’s booked for a renal ultrasound on Friday at 2 p.m.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, so the plan is for a ureteric stent, and ultrasound Friday  at 1400. 

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: For pain he’s had Endone as needed and regular Panadol. Observations have been stable and remain unchanged .QADDS of zero.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Ian, how’s your pain right now?
[PATIENT]: Still there, but the tablets take the edge off.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. I’ll keep on top of your regulars and let the team know if it ramps up.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Anything else outstanding?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: We will wait for a time for the stent and the ultrasound on Friday.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Ian, your call bell is within reach—press if you need anything. I’ll be back shortly to check your obs and pain.
[PATIENT]: Thanks.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]:  Good Morning, Nicholas. I’m Mia, I’ll be looking after you today. I’m just getting handover from Sam, the night nurse. Is that okay?
[PATIENT]: Sure, that’s fine.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Nicholas. So, this is Room 3, Bed 1: Nicholas Ferrer, 64, under Dr. Morris. Admitted with painful urination, haematuria, and reported fevers prior to admission.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Nicholas, could you tell us your full name, please, while I check your ID band?
[PATIENT]: Nicholas Ferrer.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you, matches the band. 
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He has a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes diet-controlled, depression, GORD, and gout.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Observations have been stable and he’s afebrile on the ward.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any pain right now, Nicholas?
[PATIENT]: A bit of burning when I go, but otherwise okay.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: We’ll keep an eye on that and use what’s charted if you need it.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: We still need to collect a urine MCS, and he is for bloods tomorrow morning as per the request.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll make sure the urine specimen pot is at the bedside and labelled, and we’ll collect it next when you void. 
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s still for the team review today.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Under Dr. Morris so we’ll watch for their round.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He's on a diabetic diet and his BGLs are BD as ordered.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any issues with intake?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He is Eating and drinking fine and is self-caring and can mobilise independently.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. No falls risk concerns noted?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No, he’s steady.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Nicholas, the plan from here isto get a urine sample off to the lab, check your sugars twice today, and the medical team will review you. If the burning worsens or you notice more blood, please buzz us straight away.
[PATIENT]: Okay, will do.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Call bell’s within reach here—do you have it?
[PATIENT]: Yep, right here.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE] Nicholas, can I get you anything before we head off?
[PATIENT]: I’m fine, thanks.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll be back shortly to set up the specimen and do your obs.
