example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]:Good Morning. I’m taking over now, shall we do bedside handover?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi Paulos, this is Maria. She’ll be your nurse today.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hello, Mr Gomez Castillo. I’m Maria, your nurse. We’ll talk about your care now—okay?
[PATIENT]: Okay.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Bed 2, This is Paulos Gomez Castillo, 74, under Dr Willow. He came in recently with renal colic—kidney stones—and has a long cardiac history noted in the file.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: He's got a complex cardiac history, I’ll review the notes after handover.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He has multiple allergies—documented in the chart—and he’s wearing an allergy band.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I can see the red allergy band—thank you. 
[PATIENT]: Yes.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s on a soft, cut-up diet. Obs have been stable QADDS of zero.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: BP looks good at 110/80.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s VRE positive so he is on contact precautions.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll make sure the family know how to put on PPE. 

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s waiting for  a chest X-ray and there is no confirmed time yet.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll keep him ready for when they call for him.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s on prophylactic Clexane, BD.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Is today’s doses charted?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, they’re charted.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He is NFR, but still for all regular meds and therapies.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Not for resuscitation is the paperwork completed and in the chart?

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, it is, He becomes intermittently confused and can be quite agitated at times.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Is there anything that triggers him overnight?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No its Mostly in the evening; he needs reorientation and a calm approach helped.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: he’s from a non‑English background but he understands some English. An Interpreter can be arranged if needed.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. Paulos, if you need toilet or water, press the bell—okay?
[PATIENT]: Bell—okay.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: The staff assist when walking, with a forearm support frame.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay We’ll use a gait belt as needed.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He has an IDC in situ. Urine is being recorded on the fluid balance chart. His output has been low overnight so will need to be checked hourly. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll check the catheter and continue fluid balance documentation.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any IV access?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No IVs currently.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any pain right now, Paulos?
[PATIENT]: Little… okay.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Small pain—okay, I’ll check your charted analgesia.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: So the plan for today is to maintain contact precautions; monitor obs; give Clexane BD; soft cut-up diet; staff‑assist mobilising with forearm frame; monitor confusion/agitation and reorient; keep ready for chest X‑ray; continue IDC care and fluid balance.
[PATIENT]: Okay.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Anything you need now, Paulos?
[PATIENT]: Water… small.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll bring some water and sit you up. Thanks for the handover.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks. Call me if you need anything else before I head off.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, Edwin. I’m taking over your care from the night nurse. Is it okay if we do your bedside handover now?
[PATIENT]: Sure.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Edwin. So, room 1 bed 3, this is Edwin Palma, 54, under Dr. Willow. Can I just confirm your identity?
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Edwin.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He has prostate cancer so He has come in for an assessment. He’s had a CT abdomen and an x-ray; both results are still pending.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: When were they done.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: 1000 am this morning. The plan is that he will be discharged if results are negative; otherwise he’ll be treated as an outpatient. We’re still awaiting the team’s review and the go-ahead. Otherwise, he’s stable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll keep an eye out for the results and page the team for review once they’re available.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Edwin, how are you feeling right now—any pain or new concerns?
[PATIENT]: I’m okay. No new issues.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Great. There are no immediate nursing issues to flag. His Vitals and status stable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: All right. Edwin, once the doctors review your scans, we’ll let you know the outcome and next steps. If you’re cleared, we’ll arrange your discharge; if not, we’ll organise the outpatient plan.
[PATIENT]: Sounds good. Thank you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Do you need anything before we go?
[PATIENT]: I’m fine, thanks.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. I’ll hand over the pager to you. Thanks, Edwin.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll be back shortly to update you when we hear from the team.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning. I’ll take over from here—shall we do bedside handover for Bed 3?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Sure. Hi Evan, this is Mia, she’ll be looking after you today.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Evan. Can you tell me your name and age?
[PATIENT]: Evan Stephenson, 22.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Evan. We’ll chat while we check a few things.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: So, Bed 3: Evan Stephenson, 22 years old. He came in after a fall and has rhabdomyolysis with acute kidney failure. He had very low blood pressure in ED and received a Gelofusine infusion stat. He’s more stable now, which is why he’s been transferred to the ward.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s got an IDC in situ, and for strict fluid balance charting. IV fluids are running at 803 mL per hour as charted.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Just confirming—eight-zero-three per hour? I’ll double-check the order and the pump after handover.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, that’s correct per the current order.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s on lying and standing blood pressures, daily weights, and daily bloods.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He appears swollen and bruised on the left side of his body. He’s for a review regarding his mobility. At the moment he’s resting in bed and currently stable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Evan, any pain right now, or dizziness?
[PATIENT]: Bit sore on the left side, but I’m okay lying still.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll get your pain score shortly and make sure you’re comfortable.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Urine output’s being tracked on the fluid balance?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes—IDC is patent and draining, the FBC is up to date.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. I’ll check your IV fluids, review the orthostatic BP plan, and keep up with the daily weights and bloods. I’ll also follow up on the mobility review.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. That’s everything from me.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Evan, is there anything you need right now before I check your pumps and observations?
[PATIENT]: Some water if I’m allowed?
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll confirm your fluid orders and be right back. Use your call bell if you need anything.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Alex. I’m Priya, I’ll be looking after you today. I’m just going to get bedside handover from Sam, the night nurse. Is that okay?
[PATIENT]: Sure, that’s fine.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Priya. This is Alexander Marek in Room 4, under Dr Gaylor. Alex, can you confirm your full name and date of birth for us?
[PATIENT]: Alexander Marek, 12-09-58.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great, thank you. Any allergies to medications?
[PATIENT]: None that I know of.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Okay. So, Alex is 66 years old, admitted with acute on chronic renal failure. He’s on home haemodialysis normally.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He has a history of end-stage renal failure, type 2 diabetes, hypertension, and depression. He also has atrial fibrillation and is on warfarin.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: We need his warfarin level today to guide dosing. ED drew bloods but missed the warfarin/INR, so that still needs to be taken and then please get the doctors to review the result.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll take the INR straight after handover and flag it with the team.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: His potassium this morning is 6.2, so very high. The doctors are aware and we’re waiting on their treatment orders. I’ve printed the hyperkalaemia protocol and left it just outside the notes if you need it.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, I see it there. I’ll follow up for orders.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s for renal ultrasound and biopsy to be arranged by the renal team.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He's for daily weight and he’s 82 kilograms today.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: His Lying and standing blood pressures are stable—no postural drop.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: AV fistula observations are good: there’s a bruit and thrill present.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Blood glucose levels QID; latest BGL is 5.6.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Perfect. Alex, do you usually dialyze Monday, Wednesday, Friday mornings?
[PATIENT]: Yes, M-W-F in the mornings. I had dialysis yesterday.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: I’ve called the dialysis unit to let them know he’s admitted and needs scheduling while he’s here.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great, I’ll coordinate with them for the next session.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Otherwise he’s stable at the moment.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Alex, anything you want to add or anything you need right now?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m okay, thank you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll draw your INR now, and chase the team for the hyperkalaemia orders, 
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Sounds good. Thanks, Priya.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll get started now, Alex.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Lars. I’m Mia, I’ll be looking after you now. I’m just going to get handover from Sam, the night nurse, at the bedside.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Mia. This is Lars Wohler, 42 years old, Room 4, under Dr. Geller.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Lars, we’ll speak about you, and please jump in if you feel up to it.
[PATIENT]: (nods).
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He came in with sepsis with a decreasing level of consciousness, on a background of chronic renal failure stage 4 on peritoneal dialysis. He’s had a full septic workup; results are pending.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. Blood cultures sent?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, blood cultures were taken—awaiting results.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s febrile—38.6—and we’ve started IV antibiotics. He’s also on IV fluids at 83 mL per hour.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: The antibiotics are running and fluids 83 mL/hr. Any allergies documented?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: None documented so far; unable to confirm with him given the reduced consciousness.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Is he nil by mouth?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes—NBM due to decreased level of consciousness.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Analgesia/antipyretics?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s written up for IV paracetamol.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: And code status?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s for full resuscitation.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: PD?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: His peritoneal dialysis regimen needs review—Dr. Geller will come later to review and advise.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Perfect. Any other results back yet?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Nothing definitive yet; septic workup pending.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Lars, I’m going to keep you comfortable, we’ll keep your fluids and antibiotics going, and the doctor will be in to see you shortly. If you’re in pain, can you squeeze my hand?
[PATIENT]: (weak hand squeeze)
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you. We’ll also keep you NBM until it’s safe.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. I’ll check the line site, confirm the antibiotic timing, and chart the IV paracetamol. I’ll also keep an eye on temps and neuro checks, and wait for Dr. Geller’s review and culture results.
[PATIENT]: (nods)
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Sam. I’ve got it from here.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Mindy. I’m Alex. Could you please confirm your full name and date of birth?

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great, thank you. And we’re in room 4.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: So, this is Mindy Thompson, who is 63 years old. She came in about an hour ago with right upper quadrant pain on a background of a liver cyst.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s had an X-ray and a CT done; results are pending.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Her observations have been stable since arrival.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: The RUQ pain was relieved with morphine with good effect.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s for surgery, but that’s still to be organised pending imaging and surgical review.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Her mum is at the bedside in attendance.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Her Allergies haven’t been confirmed yet on the chart.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Mindy, how is your pain right now?
[PATIENT]: Much better after the morphine, just a dull ache.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, we’ll keep monitoring and can give more as prescribed if you need it. I’ll also follow up your X-ray and CT results and touch base with the surgical team about the plan and timing.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any nausea or dizziness?
[PATIENT]: No.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good. I’ll also confirm your allergy status and ensure you’re comfortable while we wait for the results. If you need anything, press the call bell. Hi there, Mum—thanks for being here.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me. Anything else you’d like to add, Mindy?
[PATIENT]: No, thank you.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. I’ll be back shortly with an update once I’ve checked your scans and spoken with the team.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Natalie. I’m Sam, I’ll be looking after you today. I’m just going to get bedside handover from Alex, is that okay?
[PATIENT]: That’s fine.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Natalie. So, this is room 4, bed 5. Patient is Natalie Caricas, 79 years old, under Dr Ross.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She came in with stomach pain and jaundice. She has a Past history  which includes diabetes and obesity. She’s reporting feeling tired, a bit dizzy, and low in mood.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Her urine has been very dark; I’ve sent a urine MCS. She arrived on the ward about three hours ago. Admission obs and paperwork are done, and her observations have been stable since arrival.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. Any mobility concerns?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, she needs assistance with walking. I’ve flagged that she should be referred to physio.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay so shes an assist with all mobilising and falls precautions in place.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: yes. Diet-wise she’s on a diabetic diet. We’re doing QID BGL monitoring, and she’s on oral hypoglycemics.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: QID BGLs and oral hypos—no insulin charted?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No insulin charted at present.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Pain management?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s charted for Endone and morphine PRN for pain. She’s been uncomfortable, so please assess and medicate as needed.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Will do.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She hasn’t been seen by the medical team yet; she’s here for further investigation. We’re awaiting the team review under Dr Ross.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Natalie, how are you feeling right now—any pain, dizziness, or nausea?
[PATIENT]: My belly still hurts, and I feel a bit light-headed. I’m also just… a bit down.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you for telling us. I’ll check your observations now, get you some pain relief if it’s due, and make sure you’re safe when you get up. We’ll also let the doctors know how you’re feeling when they come.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me: her obs are stable a urine MCS was sent, she's an assist with mobility, and is on adiabetic diet with QID BGLs, oral hypoglycemics, PRN Endone/morphine charted, awaiting team review and physio referral.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Perfect. Natalie, your call bell is within reach—please ring before you get out of bed and we’ll come and help.
[PATIENT]: Okay, thank you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Alex. I’ll take it from here.

example.text:
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. George Wallace, 78 years old. He was brought in from home following a GP request for review. He has a background of depression and possible early dementia and is now presenting with acute confusion and agitation.
[ED NURSE]: What’s been happening?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: Over the past week he’s become increasingly withdrawn, refusing meals, and expressing low mood. His GP prescribed diazepam 5 mg twice daily for agitation, but since then he’s become more confused and restless. Today he was found wandering at home, disoriented. His wife reports he’s barely eaten in two days.
[ED NURSE]: Any observations or assessments done?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: Yes, 4AT score is 7. Vitals: BP 134/76, HR 88, Temp 37.4°C, RR 18, SpO₂ 96% RA. He’s alert but disoriented to time and place. No obvious injuries. BGL 6.1.
[ED NURSE]: Current medications?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: On diazepam with last dose last night, sertraline 50 mg mane. No known allergies.
[ED NURSE]:Thanks. Anything else I should know?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: He’s been responding to reorientation during transport when and has settled when we’ve told him his name, the date and time, and that he’s on his way to the hospital. He remains settled but may need constant observations. Oh his wife is the EPOA.
[ED NURSE]: Got it. We’ll continue orientation and arrange close monitoring until the team reviews.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Robert Hughes, 72 years old, currently admitted under a Treatment Authority. Diagnosis is late-onset schizophrenia, admitted with persecutory delusions.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: What’s his presentation today?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He remains suspicious and is refusing meals, stating that his food is poisoned. He has refused his morning risperidone 0.5 mg and is declining all blood tests. He’s also refusing routine obs.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any signs of delirium?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes — 4AT score is 6. He appears intermittently disoriented and his mental state is fluctuating. Doctors have requested delirium care strategies — regular reorientation, low-stimulus environment, clear explanations. Food and fluid charts commenced.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: What’s his legal and social situation?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s under guardianship through the Office of the Public Guardian. No local family or supports.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: And the current risk and plan?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s refusing oral meds, so the team is considering alternative routes if refusal persists. Needs close supervision for nutrition, hydration, and risk of further deterioration. Maintain reorientation and escalate if agitation or aggression increases.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll continue with the delirium care approach and monitor intake and risk.

example.text:
[Outgoing Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Thomas Reid in bed 3. He’s a 79-year-old patient with limited mobility due to a recent stroke. He has a stage 2 pressure injury on his sacrum that requires dressing today.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. What’s the current status of the wound?
[Outgoing Nurse]: It’s a shallow ulcer with partial thickness skin loss. No slough or necrosis, but the area is red and moist. No signs of infection at this stage. The wound was last dressed yesterday with Mepilex Border, and it’s due for review and redressing this morning.
[Incoming Nurse]: What’s his Waterlow score?
[Outgoing Nurse]: His Waterlow score is 20, so he’s at very high risk. He’s on a pressure-relieving mattress and we’ve been repositioning him every 2 hours.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any other monitoring or interventions?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes, he has: IDC in place – draining clear urine, last emptied 2 hours ago, an IV cannula in right forearm – patent, no fluids running currently, Regular skin checks and documentation in the wound chart, his Pain score this morning was 2/10, no analgesia required
[Incoming Nurse]: Any allergies?
[Outgoing Nurse]: No known drug allergies.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll check the wound, redress with Mepilex Border, and continue pressure care and monitoring.

example.text:
[Outgoing Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mrs. Elaine Morris in bed 6. She’s an 84-year-old patient with reduced mobility following pneumonia. She has a stage 2 pressure injury on her left hip.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. What’s the current condition of the wound?
[Outgoing Nurse]: It’s a shallow ulcer with partial thickness skin loss. The wound bed is moist but clean, with mild erythema around the edges. No signs of infection. The wound care nurse reviewed it this morning and recommended Allevyn Gentle Border dressing. It’s due for redressing tomorrow unless it becomes soiled or lifts.
[Incoming Nurse]: What’s her Waterlow score?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Waterlow score is 18, so she’s at high risk. She’s currently on a standard mattress, but we need to contact QuEST to arrange a pressure-relieving mattress as soon as possible.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any other care needs?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes: She needs a full wash this morning, including peri-care. Repositioning every 2 hours is in place. No IV access currently. Oral intake is adequate. No IDC – continent of urine and bowels. Pain score is 1/10 at rest, no analgesia required. Skin checks are ongoing, and no other areas of concern noted.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll do her wash, redress the wound if needed, and follow up with QuEST for the mattress.

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi Dr. Sharma, I’d like you to review Mr. David Lang in bed 11. He’s a 71-year-old patient admitted yesterday with a left-sided ischemic stroke. He’s currently stable but showing significant right-sided weakness and difficulty with coordination.
[DOCTOR]: Thanks. What’s his current status?
[NURSE]: He’s alert and orientated, GCS 15. Vitals are stable: BP: 142/86, HR: 78 bpm, RR: 16, Temp: 36.7°C, SpO?: 96% on room air, Q-ADDS score: 2 for (BP + mobility). He’s mobilising with assistance but has poor upper limb function on the right. He’s struggling with feeding and grooming tasks. I think he’d benefit from an occupational therapy referral to assess for functional support and equipment.
[DOCTOR]: Any IV access?
[NURSE]: Yes, he has a 20G cannula in his left forearm—patent and flushed. No IV fluids running currently.
[DOCTOR]: What medications is he on?
[NURSE]; He’s currently prescribed: Aspirin 100 mg daily, Atorvastatin 40 mg nocte, Perindopril 4 mg daily, Paracetamol 1g QID PRN for comfort. No known drug allergies.
[DOCTOR]: How is he positioned?
[NURSE]: We’re using 30-degree lateral tilt positioning to offload pressure areas and support his hemiplegic side. He’s on a pressure-relieving mattress and being repositioned every 2 hours.
[DOCTOR]: Thanks. I’ll review him and put in the OT referral. Please continue neuro obs and let me know if his mobility or cognition changes.
[NURSE]: Will do. I’ll also update the allied health team and document the referral request.

[Outgoing Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. David Lang in bed 11. He’s a 71-year-old patient admitted yesterday following a left-sided ischemic stroke. He’s currently stable but has significant right-sided weakness and requires full assistance with mobility and personal care.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. What’s his current Q-ADDS score?
[Outgoing Nurse]: His Q-ADDS score is 2—based on his BP and reduced mobility.
Latest obs are BP: 142/86, HR: 78 bpm, RR: 16, Temp: 36.7°C, SpO?: 96% on room air, GCS: of 15
[Incoming Nurse]: Any pressure area concerns?
[Outgoing Nurse]: No current pressure injuries, but he’s high risk due to immobility. He’s on a pressure-relieving mattress and we’re doing 2-hourly repositioning. Skin checks are ongoing—no redness or breakdown noted.
[Incoming Nurse]: What about hygiene needs?
[Outgoing Nurse]: He requires full assistance with hygiene. He had a full wash this morning including peri-care. He’s continent of urine and bowels—opened bowels yesterday, formed stool. No IDC.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any IV access or medications?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes, he has a 20G cannula in his left forearm—patent, no IV fluids running.
Medications: Aspirin 100 mg daily, Atorvastatin 40 mg nocte, Perindopril 4 mg daily, Paracetamol 1g QID PRN
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll continue pressure care, hygiene support, and monitor his Q-ADDS.

example.text:
[Hospital Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mrs. Emily Carter, a 38-year-old patient who was admitted three days ago and has now been newly diagnosed with bipolar disorder following a manic episode. She’s being discharged today and will require follow-up in the community.
[Community Nurse]: Thanks. Can you tell me a bit about her presentation?
[Hospital Nurse]: She was admitted after displaying elevated mood, pressured speech, and impulsive behaviour. No psychotic features noted. She’s now stabilised on medication and insight is improving. She’s aware of her diagnosis and has been engaging well with the mental health team.
[Community Nurse]: What’s her current medication regimen?
[Hospital Nurse]: She’s been started on: Lithium carbonate 400 mg BD – levels to be monitored, Quetiapine 300 mg nocte, PRN lorazepam 1 mg for agitation – not required in the last 48 hours there are No known drug allergies.
[Community Nurse]: Any physical health concerns?
[Hospital Nurse]: Vitals are stable. She’s independent with ADLs. No pressure areas noted. She’s been eating and drinking well, and her fluid balance is normal. Bowels have been regular.
[Community Nurse]: What’s her home situation?
[Hospital Nurse]: She lives with her husband and three children aged 4, 7, and 12, plus a dog. Her husband has been very supportive and is aware of the diagnosis. He’s keen to be involved in her care and has asked for education around mood monitoring and medication.
[Community Nurse]: Any follow-up arranged?
[Hospital Nurse]: Yes, she’s been referred to the community mental health team for ongoing support, including mood tracking, medication adherence, and psychoeducation. She’ll also need a home visit within 48 hours to assess safety and support needs.
[Community Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll follow up with the family and ensure she’s linked in with the right services.
[Hospital Nurse]: Great. Let me know if you need anything further from the inpatient team.

example.text:
[Transferring Hospital Nurse]: Hi Dr. Patel, I’m handing over Mr. Anthony Reid, a 64-year-old patient who was admitted earlier today with a ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). He’s being transferred to your unit for ongoing cardiac management and potential intervention.
[Receiving Doctor]: Thanks. What’s his current status?
[Transferring Hospital Nurse]: He’s currently on: IV Heparin infusion – weight-based protocol, currently running at 1000 units/hr, IV GTN infusion – titrated to chest pain, currently at 10 mcg/min, Oxygen therapy – 4 L/min via nasal prongs, saturations are sitting around 89–91% on oxygen. He’s still reporting mild chest tightness but is hemodynamically stable.
[Receiving Doctor]: Any recent observations?
[Transferring Hospital Nurse]: Yes, latest obs: BP: 104/68, HR: 96 bpm, RR: 20, Temp: 36.8°C , SpO?: 91% on 4 L O?, Q-ADDS score: 6 (due to low SpO?, chest pain, and IV therapy)
[Receiving Doctor]: Any IV access?
[Transferring Hospital Nurse]: Yes, he has a 16G cannula in the left antecubital fossa and a 20G in the right forearm. Both are patent and flushed. GTN and heparin are running through separate lines.
[Receiving Doctor]: Any other medications?
[Transferring Hospital Nurse]:
He’s also had: Aspirin 300 mg stat, Ticagrelor 180 mg stat, Atorvastatin 80 mg stat, Morphine 2.5 mg IV PRN – last dose was 2 hours age. No known drug allergies.
[Receiving Doctor]: Any investigations done?
[Transferring Hospital Nurse]: Yes, ECG confirmed anterior STEMI. Troponin is elevated. Chest X-ray shows mild pulmonary congestion. Bloods including FBC, U&E, and coagulation profile have been sent—awaiting results.
[Receiving Doctor]: Thanks. We’ll prepare for his arrival and continue cardiac monitoring. Please send through the medication chart and infusion protocols.
[Transferring Hospital Nurse]: Will do. I’ll also include his fluid balance chart and latest obs summary.

example.text:
[Outgoing Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Daniel Brooks in bed 8. He’s a 70-year-old patient who had an angiogram and ICD placement earlier today following recurrent ventricular arrhythmias. He’s now in recovery and being monitored closely.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. How did the procedure go?
[Outgoing Nurse]: The procedure was uneventful. ICD was successfully implanted. Post-procedure ECG shows a junctional rhythm, rate around 50–60 bpm. He’s asymptomatic but under continuous cardiac monitoring.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any IV access?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes, he has a 20G cannula in his left forearm, patent and flushed. No IV fluids running currently—he’s tolerating oral intake.
[Incoming Nurse]: What medications is he on?
[Outgoing Nurse]:
He’s charted for: Aspirin 100 mg daily, Bisoprolol 5 mg daily, Atorvastatin 40 mg nocte, Paracetamol 1g QID PRN he has No known drug allergies.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any post-op care instructions?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes: Keep the ICD site dry and intact—dressing checked and clean, monitor for signs of infection or bleeding, Observe cardiac rhythm closely—junctional rhythm noted, notify cardiology if symptomatic or rate drops further, 4-hourly obs unless otherwise directed his Pain score is currently 2/10, settled with Paracetamol, and Encourage gentle mobilisation with supervision.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any other concerns?
[Outgoing Nurse]: He’s alert and orientated. No nausea or dizziness. Bowels not yet open post-procedure. Fluid balance is being monitored—input ~800 mL, output ~500 mL so far.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll continue monitoring and escalate if rhythm changes or symptoms develop.

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi Dr. Ahmed, I need you to urgently review Mr. Leonard Price in bed 10. He’s a 76-year-old patient with a history of congestive heart failure and COPD. He’s deteriorated over the last few hours with worsening shortness of breath and low oxygen saturations.
[DOCTOR]:
What’s happening currently?
[NURSE]: He’s tachypnoeic and using accessory muscles. His SpO? is 86% on 6 L via Hudson mask. He’s visibly distressed and unable to speak in full sentences. Auscultation reveals coarse crackles bilaterally. He’s likely fluid overloaded—his legs are oedematous, and his fluid balance is +1800 mL over the last 48 hours.
[DOCTOR]: What are his latest observations?
[NURSE]: BP: 158/92, HR: 112 bpm, RR: 32, Temp: 37.1°C, SpO?: 86% on 6 L O?, he’s  Alert but anxious his Q-ADDS score: 8 (SpO? + RR + HR + respiratory distress)
[DOCTOR]: Any current respiratory support?
[NURSE]: Not yet, but I believe he needs to be started on BiPAP. I’ve prepped the machine and mask. He’s not tolerating high-flow oxygen and is tiring.
[DOCTOR]: IV access?
[NURSE]: Yes, he has a 22G cannula in his right forearm, patent. No current IV fluids running. He’s on a fluid restriction chart.
[DOCTOR]: Medications?
[NURSE]:
He’s charted for: Frusemide 40 mg IV BD – last dose was this morning, Spiriva inhaler daily, PRN salbutamol neb – given 1 hour ago, Paracetamol 1g QID PRN. He has No known allergies.
[DOCTOR]: Thanks. We’ll start BiPAP immediately and arrange for transfer to HDU or the respiratory unit. Please continue monitoring and notify me of any changes.
[NURSE]: Will do. I’ll document the escalation and prep for transfer.

example.text:
[Outgoing Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mrs. Joan Ellis in bed 2. She’s an 81-year-old patient admitted with a urinary tract infection and worsening confusion. She’s currently alert but disoriented and has been incontinent of both urine and bowels during the shift.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. What’s her current Q-ADDS score?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Her Q-ADDS score is 5—based on confusion, elevated temperature, and increased respiratory rate. Latest observations are BP: 132/78, HR: 94 bpm, RR: 22, Temp: 38.3°C, SpO?: 96% on room air, she is Alert but confused.
[Incoming Nurse]: Is she on any monitoring charts?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes, a Fluid Balance Chart – she’s had ~900 mL oral intake today, and incontinent of urine twice. A Bowel Chart – opened bowels once this morning, loose stool and a Falls Risk Chart – high risk due to confusion and mobility issues.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any pressure area concerns?
[Outgoing Nurse]: No current injuries, but she’s at risk. She’s on a pressure-relieving mattress and being repositioned every 2 hours. Skin checks are ongoing—no redness noted.
[Incoming Nurse]: What about hygiene?
[Outgoing Nurse]: She’s had a full wash this morning, including peri-care. She’ll likely need another wash later due to incontinence. Continence aids are in use.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any IV access or medications?
[Outgoing Nurse]: No IV access currently. She’s on: Paracetamol 1g QID, IV Ceftriaxone 1g daily – given this morning, PRN lorazepam 0.5 mg – not required today
No known allergies.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll continue monitoring, update the charts, and assist with hygiene as needed.

[NURSE 1]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Alan Roberts, 76 years old. He’s on the ward with a Stage 2 pressure injury on his right shoulder. Wound care is ongoing.
[NURSE 2]: Okay, thanks. What’s the current wound management plan?
[NURSE 1]: The area is dressed with a hydrocolloid dressing, changed every 72 hours or as needed. No signs of infection — no redness or discharge. Tissue viability nurse has reviewed and documented the plan.
[NURSE 2]: Got it. Any pain or discomfort?
[NURSE 1]: He reports mild discomfort during dressing changes but otherwise tolerating well. Analgesia charted PRN — he had paracetamol this morning.
[NURSE 2]: Any IV access?
[NURSE 1]: Yes, 22G cannula in the left forearm. It’s patent, no signs of phlebitis. Due for review tomorrow — charted for removal if no longer needed.
[NURSE 2]: I’ll check the site during rounds. Any meds due?
[NURSE 1]: No meds due right now. He’s on oral antibiotics — started two days ago for a UTI, due to complete in three more days. No known drug allergies.
[NURSE 2]: Any behavioural or cognitive concerns?
[NURSE 1]: No concerns. He’s alert, oriented, and engaging well. Mobilising with assistance. Pressure area care chart is up to date.
[NURSE 2]: Great, I’ll keep an eye on the wound and IV site. Let me know if anything changes.

example.text:
[ED Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Jack Thompson, a 45-year-old male who presented to ED following a chainsaw injury to his left lower leg sustained while working in forestry. The injury occurred approximately 90 minutes ago on-site.
[Paramedic]: Thanks. What’s his current condition?
[ED Nurse]: He’s alert and orientated, GCS 15. He’s in moderate pain but stable. The wound is deep, located on the anterolateral aspect of the left lower leg, with visible muscle and tissue damage. No active arterial bleeding, but there was significant blood loss at the scene.
[Paramedic]: Any neurovascular compromise?
[ED Nurse]:
We’ve done neurovascular obs: Sensation: Intact distal to the wound, Motor: Able to move toes, reduced strength in dorsiflexion, Capillary refill: less than 2 seconds, Pedal pulses: Present but slightly diminished compared to the right, Skin temp: Warm distally
We’re monitoring closely for compartment syndrome.
[Paramedic]: Any IV access?
[ED Nurse]: Yes, he has a 16G cannula in the right antecubital fossa, patent. He’s received 1 L Normal Saline IV and IV morphine 5 mg for pain relief.
[Paramedic]: Any other treatment so far?
[ED Nurse]: The wound has been irrigated and dressed with sterile gauze. Tetanus status is unknown—awaiting confirmation. Bloods have been taken including FBC, coagulation, and crossmatch. He’s Nil by mouth and awaiting surgical review.
[Paramedic]: Any other concerns?
[ED Nurse]: He’s a smoker, no known drug allergies, and has no significant medical history. He’s anxious but cooperative. We’ve contacted his workplace and next of kin.
[Paramedic]: Thanks. I’ll ensure safe transfer and continue monitoring neurovascular status en route

example.text:
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: Hi there, I’m bringing in Mr. Jason Taylor, 34 years old. He’s been picked up from home following a welfare check requested by his GP. He’s known to have schizophrenia and is currently experiencing an acute psychotic episode.
[ED NURSE]: What’s been happening?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: He’s been verbally aggressive, paranoid, and disorganised in speech. He believes people are trying to harm him and has been refusing food and medication for the past few days. No physical aggression during transport, but he’s restless and pacing.
[ED NURSE]: Any injuries or medical concerns?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: No injuries. Vitals are within acceptable range: BP: 118/76 , HR: 92, RR: 20, Temp: 36.9°C, SpO?: 97% on room air.
[ED NURSE]: Any known medications or allergies?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: He’s prescribed olanzapine but I don't think he’s been taking it. He has a documented allergy to penicillin—rash and swelling reported previously.
[ED NURSE]: Any substance use?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: Yes, he’s a regular cannabis user for anxiety and sleep, but he’s currently withdrawing—reports irritability and insomnia. GP flagged this as contributing to his current state. A Drug and Alcohol Team review is recommended.
[ED NURSE]: Is he medically cleared?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: He’s stable but needs a mental health assessment. No IV access yet—may need a cannula inserted if sedation or fluids are required. He’s not cooperative with physical exams. He is also under the mental health act.
[ED NURSE]: Thanks. We’ll get him triaged and notify the Mental Health Liaison Team. If needed, we’ll escalate for admission to the Mental Health Unit.
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: Perfect. He’s currently in the waiting area with security nearby. Let me know if you need anything else.

example.text:
[Hospital Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Harold Bennett, a 79-year-old resident from Greenview Aged Care Facility. He was admitted 5 days ago with a chest infection and is now medically stable and ready for discharge back to the nursing home.
[Nursing Home Nurse]: Thanks. What’s his current condition?
[Hospital Nurse]: He’s alert and orientated, though mildly fatigued. He’s completed a course of IV antibiotics—ceftriaxone—and has now transitioned to oral amoxicillin 500 mg TDS, which he’ll continue for another 3 days. His SpO? is 96% on room air, and he’s no longer requiring supplemental oxygen.
[Nursing Home Nurse]: Any ongoing care needs?
[Hospital Nurse]: Yes:  he needs Pressure area care: He’s at moderate risk (Waterlow score 16), so continue 2-hourly repositioning and maintain use of a pressure-relieving mattress. His Fluid balance chart shows he’s been drinking well, no IV fluids required. Input ~1600 mL/day, output ~1400 mL/day. The Bowel chart:  shows his Last bowel movement was yesterday—formed stool. Continue monitoring. He’s Mobilising with assistance. Physiotherapy has recommended gentle walking with a frame. His Q-ADDS score: Currently 2 (mild fatigue and recent infection). Continue routine obs twice daily unless deterioration.
[Nursing Home Nurse]: Any medications or allergies?
[Hospital Nurse]: He’s on: Amoxicillin 500 mg TDS (3 days remaining), Paracetamol 1g QID PRN, Atorvastatin 20 mg nocte, he has No known drug allergies.
[Nursing Home Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll continue monitoring and update the GP if needed.
[Hospital Nurse]: Perfect. Discharge summary and medication chart are with the transfer paperwork. Let me know if you need anything further.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, Mr. Smith. I’m Alex, I'm one of the nurses from the City Hospital where you're being transferred to. I’ll get handover from my colleague now, is that okay?
[PATIENT]: Yes, that’s fine.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: This is bed 12, John Smith, 78 years old, under Dr. Patel.
He was admitted two days ago following a fall at home, resulting in a displaced fracture of the left femur. He’s being transferred for surgical fixation.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He has a history of Type 2 Diabetes and mild dementia. He’s usually oriented to person and place but can become confused in unfamiliar environments. Observations have been stable, and pain is managed with regular paracetamol.
[INCOMING_NURSE]:
Hi Mr. Smith, can you tell us your full name to confirm your ID?
[PATIENT]: John Smith.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: And your date of birth?.
[PATIENT]: first of June 1948 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I'll check you ID number on your wristband, it's 479023, which is correct. Are you having any discomfort right now?
[PATIENT]: Just a bit of pain in my leg, but it’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No interventions overnight. Vital signs remained within normal limits: BP: 132/78, HR:88, RR:18, Temp: 36.8. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any allergies we should know about? I’ll double-check your chart as well.
[PATIENT]: Please check the chart.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Bloods from yesterday show: Hb:125, CRP:12, HbA1c:7.4 from last month. 
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s currently NBM for surgery. IV fluids are running at maintenance rate.
No anticoagulants. Pressure area care in place. Nil weight-bearing.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: So, the plan is to continue monitoring and prepare for surgical fixation. There are no outstanding tasks at this stage.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Everything is up to date.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Mr. Smith, is there anything you need before we finish handover?
[PATIENT]: No, thank you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]:
Okay, I’ll be back shortly to check on you again.

example.text:
[PHARMACIST]: Hi Dr. Lee, I wanted to speak with you about Mr. James Carter, who’s being discharged today. He’s being started on warfarin for atrial fibrillation post-op, and I’m organising his discharge medications and follow-up.
[DOCTOR]: Thanks. What’s the current plan?
[PHARMACIST]: He’s had two doses of warfarin so far—5 mg on Day 1 and 3 mg yesterday. His INR this morning was 1.6, so still subtherapeutic. I’ve charted 3 mg again today, and we’ll need to arrange ongoing INR monitoring through his GP or local pathology service.
[DOCTOR]: Okay. Has the GP been contacted?
[PHARMACIST]: Not yet. I was going to ask if you’d like to send a discharge summary with a note to the GP to monitor INR every 2–3 days initially, and adjust dosing as needed. I’ll also include a warfarin education leaflet and a yellow book for tracking.
[DOCTOR]: Yes, please include that in the discharge paperwork. Has he been counselled?
[PHARMACIST]: Yes, I’ve spoken with him about, Dietary interactions (especially vitamin K), Bleeding risks, Signs to report (e.g. bruising, blood in urine/stool), Avoiding NSAIDs and alcohol, He’s aware and has agreed to follow up with his GP.
[DOCTOR]: Great. Any other meds to note?
[PHARMACIST]: He’s also on, Metoprolol 25 mg BD, Atorvastatin 40 mg nocte, Paracetamol PRN, No known drug allergies.
[DOCTOR]: Perfect. I’ll finalise the discharge summary and include the INR plan. Thanks for organising everything.
[PHARMACIST]: No problem. I’ll send the warfarin pack with him and notify the GP clinic once he’s discharged.

[WARD NURSE 1]: Hey, just handing over James Taylor, 42 years old, admitted yesterday with severe tonsillitis. He’s heading to theatre later this morning for a tonsillectomy.
[WARD NURSE 2]: Okay, thanks. What’s his current status?
[WARD NURSE 1]: He’s afebrile now, vitals are stable — RR 16, SpO? 98% on room air, HR 82. Still has significant throat pain and is nil by mouth in preparation for surgery. ENT reviewed him this morning and confirmed he’s on the list.
[WARD NURSE 2]: Got it. Any IV access?
[WARD NURSE 1]: Yes, 20G in the right forearm — patent and secure. He’s had IV fluids and antibiotics this morning. No known drug allergies.
[WARD NURSE 2]: Any behavioural or cognitive concerns?
[WARD NURSE 1]: No concerns. He’s alert and cooperative, just a bit anxious about the procedure, which is understandable.
[WARD NURSE 2]: Has the pre-op checklist been done?
[WARD NURSE 1]: Yep — checklist complete, consent signed, anaesthetics team has reviewed. Theatre is booked for 11:30 AM. Just keep an eye out for any changes and let the team know if there’s a delay.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over bed 8, Jake Morrison, 23 years old. He’s Day 1 post-VATS for a left-sided pneumothorax following a football injury on Saturday. He’s just come back from theatre this morning.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: How’s he doing?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s stable post-op. Vitals are within normal limits. He’s alert and orientated, but still a bit groggy from anaesthetic.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any drains or lines?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, he has: One chest drain on the left side, currently on suction, IV cannula in the right forearm, PCA in place – fentanyl-based, set up and functioning
He’s been shown how to use the PCA but may need reinforcement. He’s hesitant and unsure about pressing the button.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Got it. I’ll go over it with him again.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Pain score is around 4/10 at rest, 6/10 on movement. He’s tolerating oral fluids and has had a light meal. No nausea or vomiting.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any other concerns?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s understandably anxious about the chest drain and movement. He’s due for a physio review later today to start gentle breathing exercises and mobilisation.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any allergies or medications?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No known drug allergies. Regular meds include paracetamol and ibuprofen pre-op. Post-op: Fentanyl PCA, Paracetamol 1g QID, Ondansetron PRN, Cephazolin IV (prophylactic).
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll check the drain output and reinforce PCA use.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if anything changes. He’s currently resting in bed.

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Mrs. Lien Tran, 82 years old, here for a renal ultrasound to investigate reduced kidney function. She’s from a Vietnamese-speaking background and does not speak English. She also has significant vision impairment and is deaf.
[RADIOGRAPHER]: Thanks. How does she communicate?
[NURSE]: She uses Vietnamese sign language and gestures. Her daughter is on the way and usually helps interpret. In the meantime, we’ve requested a Vietnamese interpreter, but they haven’t arrived yet. I’ve written out some basic instructions in large print Vietnamese, but she may still need assistance understanding the procedure.
[RADIOGRAPHER]: Is she medically stable?
[NURSE]: Yes, vitals are stable. She’s a bit anxious due to the unfamiliar environment and communication barriers, so a calm approach will help.
[RADIOGRAPHER]: Any mobility issues?
[NURSE]: She’s ambulant with assistance. She uses a walking frame and needs help getting on and off the bed.
[RADIOGRAPHER]: Any allergies or medications?
[NURSE]: No known drug allergies. She’s on Amlodipine 5 mg daily, Furosemide 40 mg daily, Calcium carbonates she’s Nil by mouth for the scan and has had fluids withheld this morning.
[RADIOGRAPHER]: I’ll wait for the interpreter or her daughter before starting. I’ll keep her comfortable in the meantime.
[NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if you need anything else.

[ED_NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Mrs. Lien Tran, 82 years old, transferring to your ward for further investigation of renal impairment. She’s here for a renal ultrasound to help diagnose the issue.
[WARD_NURSE]: Thanks. Can you tell me a bit about her background?
[ED_NURSE]: Sure. She’s from a Vietnamese-speaking background, does not speak English, and is deaf. She also has significant vision impairment. Communication is a challenge—she uses Vietnamese sign language and gestures, but we’ve requested a Vietnamese interpreter. Her daughter is on the way and usually helps with communication.
[WARD_NURSE]: How is she medically?
[ED_NURSE]: Her Vitals are stable, She’s alert but anxious due to the unfamiliar environment and communication barriers.
[WARD_NURSE]: Any mobility concerns?
[ED_NURSE]: She’s ambulant with assistance and uses a walking frame. Needs help with transfers and getting on/off the bed.
[WARD_NURSE]: Any medications or allergies?
[ED_NURSE]: No known drug allergies. She’s on, Amlodipine 5 mg daily, Furosemide 40 mg daily, Calcium carbonate, she’s nil by mouth for the scan and fluids have been withheld this morning.
[WARD_NURSE]:  Anything else I should be aware of?
[ED_NURSE]: Just be mindful of her communication needs and vision impairment. I’ve left a large print Vietnamese instruction sheet at the bedside, but she may still need support. Her daughter should arrive shortly and can assist.
[WARD_NURSE]: I’ll get her settled and follow up with the interpreter service.
[ED_NURSE]: Let me know if anything changes.

example.text:
[ED_NURSE]:
Hi, thanks for coming. I’m handing over Mr. Leo Martinez, 56 years old, admitted through ED earlier today with chest pain and a history of Type 2 diabetes. He also consumed a large amount of alcohol last night and presented confused and groggy.
[WARD_NURSE]: What’s his current status?
[ED_NURSE]: He’s still a bit drowsy, but responsive. Chest pain has eased slightly with initial treatment. Vitals are stable BP: 108/72, HR: 96 bpm, RR: 20, SpO?: 95% on room air, Temp: 36.7°C, BGL: 14.2 mmol/L on arrival, now 11.6 mmol/L
[DOCTOR]: We’re admitting him for cardiac monitoring and further investigation. ECG showed non-specific changes, and we’re awaiting troponin results. He’s also at risk of alcohol withdrawal, so we’ve started a CIWA protocol and charted thiamine and diazepam PRN.
[WARD_NURSE]: Any IV access?
[ED_NURSE]: Yes, he has a 20G cannula in the left forearm, patent and flushed. Fluids are running at maintenance rate.
[WARD_NURSE]: Any allergies or regular meds?
[ED_NURSE]: No known drug allergies. Regular meds include, Metformin 500 mg BD, Atorvastatin 20 mg nocte, PRN insulin sliding scale (not charted today due to alcohol intake)
[DOCTOR]: We’ll need to involve the Drug and Alcohol Team tomorrow for support. He’s also been referred to Cardiology for review.
[WARD_NURSE]: Is he safe to mobilise?
[ED_NURSE]:
Not really sure we haven't tried to get him up.
[PATIENT]: Where am I now?
[WARD_NURSE]: Hi Mr. Martinez, you’re being moved to the ward now so we can keep a close eye on your heart and help you feel better. I’ll be looking after you.
[PATIENT]: Okay… my chest still feels tight.
[DOCTOR]: We’ll keep monitoring that. Let us know if it gets worse.
[WARD_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll get him settled and continue obs and withdrawal monitoring.
[ED_NURSE]: Perfect. All documentation is up to date. Let me know if you need anything

example.text:
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Daniel Hayes, 67 years old, just returned from the cath lab following a coronary angiogram. He’s being transferred back to CCU for ongoing monitoring.
[CCU_NURSE]: Thanks. How did the procedure go?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: Procedure was uneventful. No stents placed today—angiogram was diagnostic only. He still has the femoral sheath in situ, and it needs to be transduced for haemodynamic monitoring. His heart rate is low, sitting around 48 bpm, so we’re keeping a close eye on it.
[CCU_NURSE]: Okay. What are his current vitals?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: BP: 110/68, HR: 48 bpm, sinus bradycardia, RR: 16, SpO?: 97% on room air, Temp: 36.6°C, He’s alert and orientated, but a bit tired post-procedure.
[CCU_NURSE]: Any lines or medications?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: Yes, a Femoral sheath – still in place, not yet transduced, IV cannula in left forearm, No IV infusions running currently, no sedation required post-procedure and probably has some usual meds
[CCU_NURSE]: Any pain or bleeding?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: No active bleeding. Puncture site is clean and dressed. No complaints of pain. He’s on bed rest, and we’ve reinforced strict leg immobilisation.
[CCU_NURSE]: Any medications charted?
[CCU_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll get the sheath transduced and continue monitoring his HR closely.
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if anything changes. All documentation is up to date.

example.text:
[DOCTOR]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Amir Rahman, 63 years old, admitted yesterday with what looks like a large anterior MI — the ECG was fairly convincing. He’s currently in ICU. They started an intra‑aortic balloon pump yesterday evening, mainly as a bridge to CABG, which is tentatively booked for two days from now, but that might shift depending on his stability.
[ICU_NURSE]: Thanks. Can you give me a quick overview?
[DOCTOR]: Sure. He’s still a bit haemodynamically shaky post‑MI, with ongoing low cardiac output. The IABP went in this morning via the femoral artery — I believe the cardiology registrar did it. It’s set to 1:1 augmentation. So far, he seems to be responding — BP’s come up a bit, and lactates look like they’re trending down, though the last result isn’t in yet.
[ICU_NURSE]: Any other lines or support?
[DOCTOR]: Right, he’s got an arterial line in the right radial for continuous BP monitoring, a central line in the right internal jugular, and an IDC in situ. I think he’s also still connected to telemetry, but I’ll need to double‑check if that’s linked to the central monitoring unit. He’s on low‑dose noradrenaline, sitting around 2 micrograms a minute, but that’s fluctuated a little. IV heparin is running for balloon pump patency — pharmacy flagged a possible review of APTT later today.
[ICU_NURSE]: Any communication needs?
[DOCTOR]: Yes, he’s from a non‑English speaking background — Arabic’s his first language. He understands basic English, but it’s hit‑and‑miss for more complex instructions. Somebody requested an interpreter for the family conference, but I’m not sure if it’s been booked yet. His son’s bilingual and has been helping, though he might not be around later tonight.
[ICU_NURSE]: Any pain or sedation?
[DOCTOR]: He’s alert and orientated. No sedation required at this stage. Pain’s reasonably controlled with paracetamol and occasional oxycodone — he said it’s “okay,” but sounded a bit unsure. He’s anxious — understandably — so maybe consider whether some short‑acting anxiolytic’s needed if he escalates later.
[ICU_NURSE]: Any allergies or medications?
[DOCTOR]: No known drug allergies as far as documented. Meds include aspirin 100 mg daily, atorvastatin 80 mg nocte, the IV heparin infusion, noradrenaline, and the PRNs — paracetamol and oxycodone. I’ll have to check if his beta blocker’s been restarted post‑MI; cardiology had mentioned it but I didn’t see an order yet.
[ICU_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll keep monitoring IABP function and haemodynamics closely.
[DOCTOR]: Perfect. Let me know if there’s any change in rhythm, perfusion, or balloon timing. I think the surgical team’s planning to review tomorrow morning, but if anything shifts overnight — especially haemodynamics or rhythm — just flag them or cardiac reg overnight.

preds.quote: Meds include aspirin 100 mg daily, atorvastatin 80 mg nocte, the IV heparin infusion, noradrenaline, and the PRNs — paracetamol and oxycodone. I’ll have to check if his beta blocker’s been restarted post‑MI; cardiology had mentioned it but I didn’t see an order yet

preds.label: RECOMMENDATION
preds.quote: I’ll keep monitoring IABP function and haemodynamics closely

preds.label: RECOMMENDATION
preds.quote: Let me know if there’s any change in rhythm, perfusion, or balloon timing. I think the surgical team’s planning to review tomorrow morning, but if anything shifts overnight — especially haemodynamics or rhythm — just flag them or cardiac reg overnight

[CATHLABNURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Mrs. Fatima El-Sayed, 61 years old, just returned from the cath lab following an angiogram and stent placement for an anterior STEMI. She’s being transferred back to CCU for ongoing monitoring and support.
[CCU_NURSE]: Can you give me a summary?
[CATHLABNURSE]: Sure. She had two stents placed in the LAD. The myocardium is stunned, and she’s currently supported with an intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP). It’s set to 1:1 augmentation, and she’s tolerating it well so far. She’s haemodynamically stable but requires close monitoring.
[CCU_NURSE]:
Vitals?
[CATHLABNURSE]: BP: 98/60, HR: 52 bpm – sinus bradycardia, RR: 18, SpO?: 96% on room air, Temp: 36.8°C. She’s alert but fatigued. No chest pain currently.
[CCU_NURSE]: Any lines or attachments?
[CATHLABNURSE]: she has a IABP via right femoral artery, an Arterial line in left radial a CVL in right internal jugular, an IDC in place draining over 30mls an hour. And Telemetry monitoring. She’s on IV heparin infusion for IABP patency and low-dose noradrenaline at 2 mcg/min.
[CCU_NURSE]: Any investigations pending?
[CATHLABNURSE]: Yes, she’s booked for a chest X-ray to confirm IABP positioning and a transthoracic echocardiogram to assess myocardial function. Cardiology team will review later today.
[CCU_NURSE]: Any communication needs?
[CATHLABNURSE]: Yes, she’s from a non-English speaking background—Arabic is her first language. She understands basic English but struggles with medical terms. Her daughter is bilingual and has been helping. Interpreter has been requested for ward rounds.
[CCU_NURSE]: Any allergies or medications?
[CATHLABNURSE]:
No known drug allergies. 
[CCU_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll transduce the IABP and continue monitoring closely.
[CATHLABNURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if anything changes. All documentation is up to date.

example.text:
[ED Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Luke Harris, a 42-year-old male who presented to ED following a deliberate overdose. He reportedly ingested approximately 50 Panadol tablets, 20 Serepax, and a bottle of whisky at home after an argument with his partner.
[Paramedic]: Thanks. What’s his current condition?
[ED Nurse]: He arrived via ambulance, drowsy but rousable. He’s currently confused, slurred speech, and intermittently agitated. He’s on 2 L/min oxygen via nasal prongs, but his SpO? is sitting around 92%. He’s a smoker, and his respiratory rate is slightly depressed at 10–12 breaths per minute.
[Paramedic]: Any vitals or Q-ADDS score?
[ED Nurse]: Yes, latest observations: BP: 118/76, HR: 88 bpm, RR: 12, Temp: 36.5°C, SpO?: 92% on 2 L O?, GCS: 13 and a Q-ADDS score: 6 (due to RR, SpO?, confusion, and overdose)
[Paramedic]: Any IV access or treatment started?
[ED Nurse]: Yes, he has a 20G cannula in his right forearm, patent. We’ve started IV fluids (Normal Saline) and drawn bloods for paracetamol levels, LFTs, and coagulation profile. Activated charcoal was not given due to delayed presentation and reduced consciousness.
[Paramedic]: Any social concerns?
[ED Nurse]: Yes, he lives with his partner and has been in a verbal altercation prior to the overdose. He has no known mental health diagnosis, but this appears to be a first-time overdose. He has no children at home but reports high alcohol use and smoking daily.
[Paramedic]: Any plans for transfer?
[ED Nurse]: Yes, he’s being transferred to the medical ward for monitoring and possible N-acetylcysteine infusion pending paracetamol levels. Mental health team will review once medically stable.
[Paramedic]: Okay, I’ll update the receiving team and ensure safe transfer.

[ED NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Maria Santos, 58 years old, coming up to the ward with cellulitis on her left lower leg. She’s been started on IV antibiotics and is stable for transfer.
[WARD NURSE]: Thanks. What’s her current status?
[ED NURSE]: Vitals are stable — temp 37.6°C, HR 84, BP 122/78, RR 18, SpO? 98% on room air. The affected leg is red, warm, and swollen from mid-calf to ankle. No signs of abscess or necrosis.
[WARD NURSE]: Okay. What’s the antibiotic plan?
[ED NURSE]: She’s on IV cefazolin, 1g every 8 hours. First dose was given in ED about an hour ago. Next dose is due at 10 PM. No known drug allergies.
[WARD NURSE]: Got it. Any IV access?
[ED NURSE]: Yes, 20G cannula in the right forearm — site is clean, dry, and patent. Charted for daily review. She’s also had IV fluids earlier, but now tolerating oral intake.
[WARD NURSE]: Any pain management?
[ED NURSE]: She’s had paracetamol 1g orally — pain is currently 4/10. PRN analgesia is charted.
[WARD NURSE]: Any behavioural or cognitive concerns?
[ED NURSE]: No concerns. She’s alert, oriented, and understands the treatment plan. Mobilising with assistance due to leg discomfort.
[WARD NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll check the IV site and meds when she arrives. Let me know if anything changes before transfer.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, Ms. Carter. I’m Jack, and I’ll be your nurse for today. We’ll do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Ms. Carter. This is the nurse taking over for the day. Could you please confirm your full name?
[PATIENT]: Emily Carter.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you. This is Ms. Emily Carter in Bed 6, Room 14, aged 29, under Dr. Thompson, General Surgeon.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Ms. Carter is Day 1 post-op from a laparoscopic appendectomy. She returned from theatre yesterday afternoon. Her vital signs have remained stable overnight. She’s currently tolerating oral fluids and has transitioned to a light diet this morning.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Pain is being managed with regular oral analgesia. No nausea or vomiting reported. Her wound sites are clean and dry, with dressings intact. She’s mobilised to the bathroom with assistance and tolerated it well.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Ms. Carter, how are you feeling this morning? Any pain or discomfort?
[PATIENT]: Just a bit sore around the belly, but otherwise okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Pain score was 3/10 on movement earlier. Dr. Thompson reviewed her this morning and is happy with her progress. Discharge planning will depend on how she tolerates diet and mobilises today.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll keep monitoring your pain and mobility and check in with Dr. Thompson’s team later today. Is there anything you need before we finish handover?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m fine for now.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Please use the call bell if you need anything. I’ll leave you in good hands.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll be back shortly to check your observations and review your chart, Ms. Carter.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, Ms. Nguyen. I’m Jack, and I’ll be your nurse for today. We’ll do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Ms. Nguyen. This is the nurse taking over for the day. Could you please confirm your full name?
[PATIENT]: Linh Nguyen.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you. This is Ms. Linh Nguyen in Bed 3, Room 5, aged 34, under Dr. Patel, Psychiatry Registrar.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Ms. Nguyen presented yesterday following suicidal ideation and low mood. She was brought in by her sister after expressing thoughts of self-harm. She has no current injuries. Observations have remained stable overnight. She’s alert, tearful at times, and has engaged minimally with staff.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: A mental health review is scheduled for this morning. A social worker has also been involved to support psychosocial needs and coordinate with family. Her sister and mother are present and have requested to be involved in care planning.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Hi Linh, I’m Amina, one of the hospital social workers. I understand you’ve been going through a really difficult time. Would it be okay if we talked for a few minutes?
[PATIENT]: Okay.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Thank you. I want to make sure you feel safe and supported. You mentioned feeling overwhelmed—can you tell me a little about what’s been happening?
[PATIENT]: I just feel like I can’t cope anymore. Everything’s too much.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: I’m really sorry you’re feeling this way. You’re not alone, and we’re here to help. Your sister and mum are here and want to support you. Would you be comfortable if we invited them in to talk together?
[PATIENT]: Yes, I think so.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Okay. We’ll also work with Dr. Patel and the mental health team to make sure you have a plan in place before discharge—whether that’s follow-up care, counselling, or community support. We’ll take it one step at a time.
SISTER]: Linh, we’re here for you. We didn’t know how bad things were, but we want to help however we can.
[MOTHER]: We love you. We’ll do whatever it takes to support you.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Thank you both. We’ll work together to make sure Linh has the right care and support moving forward.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, Mr. Fraser. I’m Jack, and I’ll be your nurse for today. We’ll just do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, if that’s alright.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Mr. Fraser. Could you please confirm your full name?
[PATIENT]: Andrew Fraser.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you and your date of birth? 
[PATIENT]: Twenty-third of August 1958. 
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Great and your URN on that armband says 893745 that matches your chart. So Mr Fraser is under the cardiothoracic surgeon covering this list - not sure who.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He was admitted yesterday for a planned aortic valve replacement due to severe aortic stenosis. He’s currently stable, nil by mouth, and awaiting theatre — I think the procedure’s still set for this afternoon, though final time hasn’t been confirmed yet. Pre‑op bloods and ECG were done and look okay from what I saw, but anaesthetics still need to recheck his potassium levels. Consent’s signed and documented.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s on his regular cardiac medications — they were reviewed by the anaesthetics registrar this morning, or possibly one of the fellows. No chest pain or shortness of breath that he’s mentioned overnight. Vitals all fine — around baseline. He’s aware of the procedure and quite anxious, understandably; I reassured him but might be worth chatting again before transfer.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Mr. Fraser, how are you feeling this morning? Any discomfort or anything worrying you?
[PATIENT]: Just nervous, really. No pain.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Of course. His wife’s planning to come in later today — she wasn’t sure what time yet. Theatre team should ring the ward once they’ve finalised scheduling, but I haven’t heard back this morning. He’s got family contact details in the chart if anyone needs to update them.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll follow up with the surgical team and confirm timing when possible. Is there anything you need before we finish handover?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Great. Please use the call bell if you need anything. I’ll be finishing soon, but the coordinator’s around if anything changes.

[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: Hi there, I’m bringing in Mrs. Margaret Ellis, 87 years old, from Rosewood Nursing Home. She had a fall earlier this morning—staff found her on the floor next to her bed. She’s hit her head, and there’s a small occipital hematoma. No loss of consciousness reported, but she’s been drowsy and confused since.
[ED NURSE]: Thanks. Any known medical history?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: Yes, she has: Hypertension, Osteoarthritis, Early-stage dementia and a Profound hearing loss – she’s deaf and communicates via written notes and gestures. No hearing aids in place today.
[ED NURSE]: Any medications or allergies?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: She’s on amlodipine and paracetamol regularly. No known drug allergies.
[ED NURSE]: What’s her current condition?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]:
Vitals on arrival: BP: 102/64, HR: 88, RR: 18, Temp: 36.7°C, SpO?: 97% on room air
She’s responsive but confused. No vomiting. GCS is 14.
[ED NURSE]: Any advanced care directives?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: Yes, nursing home staff provided documentation indicating a Do Not Resuscitate (DNR) order. There’s also a note that family must be involved in any escalation decisions. Her daughter and son are on their way to the hospital now.
[ED NURSE]: Thanks. Any IV access?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: No IV inserted yet. She may need one for imaging or fluids depending on your assessment.
[ED NURSE]:  We’ll get her triaged and notify the medical team. I’ll also make sure we have written communication tools available for her.
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: Perfect. She’s currently calm but may need reassurance once she’s in the bay.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, Mr. Patel. I’m Jack, and I’ll be your nurse for today. We’ll do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Mr. Patel. This is the nurse taking over for the day. Could you please confirm your full name?
[PATIENT]: Rakesh Patel.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you. This is Mr. Rakesh Patel in Bed 1, Room 3, aged 58, under Dr. Morrison, General Surgeon.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Mr. Patel was admitted this morning for an elective inguinal hernia repair. He’s nil by mouth and awaiting theatre. Pre-op bloods, ECG, and consent have been completed. He’s aware of the procedure and has no concerns at this stage.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s hemodynamically stable. No pain reported currently. He’s had mild discomfort over the past few weeks, especially with lifting. No signs of strangulation or obstruction. Vitals are within normal limits.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Mr. Patel, how are you feeling this morning? Any pain or nausea?
[PATIENT]: No pain right now, just a bit nervous.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Understandable. He’s been reassured and is coping well. No allergies. Medications include atorvastatin 20mg daily and paracetamol PRN. No anticoagulants. No previous surgeries.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll follow up with the surgical team and theatre staff. Is there anything you need before we finish handover?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m okay. Thanks.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Please use the call bell if you need anything. I’ll leave you in good hands.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll be back shortly to check your observations and review your chart, Mr. Patel.

example.text:
[PARAMEDIC]: Hi, this is John, paramedic with Metro Ambulance. We’ve brought in Ms. Helen Morris, aged 72, from home. She’s currently in Bed 6, Isolation Bay 2.
[PARAMEDIC]: Ms. Morris was referred by her GP due to increasing shortness of breath, productive cough, and low-grade fever over the past 3 days. Her GP suspected RSV due to recent community cases and her history of COPD. She lives with her husband, who is currently well.
[PARAMEDIC]: On arrival, she was SpO? 91% on room air, now on 2L nasal prongs, saturating at 95%. RR 22, HR 88, BP 138/82, Temp 37.8°C. She’s alert and oriented but fatigued.
[PARAMEDIC]: We’ve placed her in isolation as a precaution. Full PPE is being used. She’s been cooperative and understands the need for precautions. No known allergies. Regular medications include tiotropium, salbutamol, and amlodipine.
[PARAMEDIC]: No recent hospital admissions. She’s had two doses of COVID vaccine and annual flu shot. No RSV test done yet—GP advised swab on arrival.
[PARAMEDIC]: She’s stable for now. No chest pain or confusion. Handover complete—do you have any questions?
[ED NURSE]: Thanks, John. I’ll get her settled and notify the medical team for review and swabbing. I’ll continue isolation precautions and monitor her respiratory status.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, Mr. Jackson. I’m Sarah, and I’ll be your nurse for today. We’ll do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Mr. Jackson. This is the nurse taking over for the day. Could you please confirm your full name?
[PATIENT]: David Jackson.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you. This is Mr. David Jackson in Bed 4, Room 6, aged 64, under Dr. Patel, Orthopaedic Consultant.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Mr. Jackson is awaiting ORIF surgery for a left femoral neck fracture, scheduled for tomorrow. He’s been stable overnight, but this morning he reported lower abdominal discomfort and has not passed urine since yesterday evening.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Bladder scan showed retention of 650 mL. Medical team reviewed and requested an IDC insertion. He’s alert, cooperative, and understands the procedure. No known allergies. Pain is currently 3/10 on movement.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Mr. Jackson, I’ll be inserting a catheter shortly to help relieve the pressure in your bladder. I’ll explain everything before we begin.
[PATIENT]: Okay, thank you. It’s really uncomfortable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I understand. I’ll get everything ready now.
[SARAH]: Hey, Jess—sorry to interrupt. I’ve got a patient in Room 6 with urinary retention and needs an IDC. I haven’t done one before—would you mind assisting or supervising?
[JESS]: Of course, happy to help. Let’s grab the trolley and go through it together. I’ll walk you through the steps.
[SARAH]: Thanks so much. I’ve read the protocol, just haven’t had the chance to do one hands-on yet.
[JESS]: No worries—we’ll take it slow and make sure Mr. Jackson is comfortable throughout.
[NURSE SARAH]: Hi Mr. Jackson, I just wanted to check in. I understand you’re still feeling quite uncomfortable.
[PATIENT]: Yes, I still haven’t been able to pass urine. It’s getting worse.
[NURSE SARAH]: I’m sorry to hear that. We’ve done a bladder scan and it shows you’re retaining quite a bit—over 700 mL. The doctor will be coming shortly to insert a catheter to relieve the pressure.
[PATIENT]: Okay, thank you.
[NURSE SARAH]: Hi Dr. Patel, sorry to interrupt. Mr. Jackson in Room 6 has urinary retention—bladder scan shows 740 mL. I attempted an IDC but met resistance and he was quite uncomfortable. Would you be able to insert it?
[DR. PATEL]: Yes, I can do that. Can you get the trolley set up and let me know when it’s ready?
[NURSE SARAH]: Absolutely. I’ll prepare the sterile field now.
[NURSE SARAH]: Dr. Patel, the trolley is set up and Mr. Jackson has been informed. He’s ready when you are.
[DR. PATEL]: Great, let’s go ahead. Can you assist with maintaining the sterile field?
[NURSE SARAH]: Of course.

example.text:
[NURSE AMY]: Good morning, Ms. Carter. I’m Amy, and I’ll be your nurse for today. We’ll do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Ms. Carter. This is the nurse taking over for the day. Could you please confirm your full name?
[PATIENT]: Jessica Carter.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you. This is Ms. Jessica Carter in Bed 5, Room 11, aged 35, under Dr. Nguyen, Orthopaedic Consultant.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Ms. Carter was admitted yesterday following a fall at home. She has a displaced fracture of the right humerus and is scheduled for ORIF surgery tomorrow morning. She’s currently in a sling and on regular analgesia. Pain score was 6/10 earlier, now 3/10 after medication.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Neurovascular obs are intact: her Capillary refill <2 seconds, Sensation present, her Movement limited due to pain but preserved, there is No swelling or discoloration noted
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s a single mother of two young children and has expressed concern about managing at home post-op. A social worker referral has been made to explore home support and childcare options.
[PHYSIOTHERAPIST]: Hi Jessica, I’m Priya from physio. I’ve reviewed your chart and will work with you post-op to help regain movement and strength in your arm. For now, just rest and keep the arm supported. After surgery, we’ll start gentle exercises and discuss strategies for managing daily tasks one-handed.
[PATIENT]: Okay, I’m worried about how I’ll manage with the kids.
[PHYSIOTHERAPIST]: That’s understandable. We’ll work closely with the social worker and nursing team to make sure you have the right support in place.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Hi Jessica, I’m Mark from social work. I understand you’re concerned about managing at home after surgery. Can you tell me a bit about your current support system?
[PATIENT]: It’s just me and the kids. My mum lives interstate and I don’t have anyone nearby.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Thanks for sharing. I’ll look into short-term home care options and community support services. We can also explore childcare assistance while you recover. I’ll keep you updated and help with any paperwork.
[NURSE AMY]: I’ll continue monitoring your pain and neurovascular status, and coordinate with the surgical team. Let me know if you need anything, Jessica.
[PATIENT]: Thank you. I really appreciate it.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over bed 7, Mr. David Tran, 62 years old. He’s been admitted with non-small cell lung cancer affecting the left upper lobe. He’s scheduled for a left pneumonectomy tomorrow morning.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. What’s happening currently?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s stable at present. Pre-op workup is complete—he’s had a CT chest, PET scan, and pulmonary function tests. Anaesthetics and thoracics have reviewed him. He’s fasting from midnight and has been consented for surgery.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any symptoms or concerns?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s mildly anxious, understandably. No respiratory distress, oxygen saturations are 96% on room air. He’s been coughing occasionally but no haemoptysis. Pain is well controlled with regular paracetamol.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any comorbidities?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes—hypertension and type 2 diabetes, both well-managed. He’s on metformin and amlodipine. No known allergies.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any communication or support needs?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: English is his second language—Vietnamese is his first. He understands most conversations but prefers simple explanations. Interpreter has been booked for the surgical consent and post-op education. His wife is his next of kin and has been very involved.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any other prep needed?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s had pre-op bloods, ECG, and group and hold done. TEDs are on, and he’s been educated on incentive spirometry. Surgical checklist is complete. Just needs pre-op IV fluids started at 6 am.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Got it. I’ll keep an eye on his anxiety and ensure he’s ready for theatre.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if anything changes overnight. All documentation is up to date.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, I’M Brad am I’m handing over bed 12, Mrs. Maria Giannopoulos, 81 years old. She’s been admitted for severe symptomatic aortic stenosis and is scheduled for a TAVI tomorrow morning.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. What’s happening currently?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s stable. No chest pain or syncope overnight. She’s NYHA Class III—gets breathless on minimal exertion. Vitals are within normal limits, and she’s on telemetry. No arrhythmias noted.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Has she been reviewed by the team?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, cardiology and interventional have reviewed. She’s been consented, and the procedure is booked for 8:00 AM. She’s fasting from midnight. Pre-op checklist is complete.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any comorbidities?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes—hypertension, chronic kidney disease stage 3, and mild cognitive impairment. She’s on perindopril, frusemide, and aspirin. No known allergies.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any communication needs?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: English is her second language—Greek is her first. She understands most things but prefers slow, clear explanations. Interpreter has been arranged for the morning. Her son is her substitute decision-maker and has been involved in all discussions.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any concerns overnight?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She was a bit anxious about the procedure but settled after reassurance. No acute issues. She’s continent, mobilising with assistance, and on a low-sodium diet.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Got it. I’ll keep her calm and prep her for theatre in the morning.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if anything changes. All documentation is up to date, including the consent and pre-op orders.
