example.text:
[OUTGOING ED NURSE]: Hi, I'm handing over bed 9, Mr. Jamal Khan, 28 years old. He’s presented to ED with diabetic ketoacidosis. He has type 1 diabetes, diagnosed at age 14.
[INCOMING WARD NURSE]: Thanks. What brought him in?
[OUTGOING ED NURSE]: He’s had three days of nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. He stopped taking insulin due to poor oral intake. He was tachypnoeic and dehydrated on arrival. Capillary ketones were 6.8, BGL was 28.4, and venous pH was 7.12.
[INCOMING WARD NURSE]: What’s been done so far?
[OUTGOING ED NURSE]: He’s been managed as per the DKA protocol—IV fluids, fixed-rate insulin infusion, and hourly BGL and ketone monitoring. Electrolytes are being replaced as needed. He’s improving—ketones are now 2.4, and pH is 7.28. Still on insulin infusion.
[INCOMING WARD NURSE]: Any complications?
[OUTGOING ED NURSE]: No cerebral oedema or arrhythmias. He’s alert and oriented, tolerating sips of water. No vomiting since arrival. Vitals are stable—HR 92, BP 118/72, RR 20, SpO? 98% on room air.
[INCOMING WARD NURSE]: Any comorbidities or allergies?
[OUTGOING ED NURSE]: No other medical history. No known drug allergies. He’s usually on basal-bolus insulin at home—Lantus and Novorapid.
[INCOMING WARD NURSE]: Any social or communication needs?
[OUTGOING ED NURSE]: English is his first language. Lives alone, works full-time. He’s anxious about being admitted but cooperative. Diabetes educator has been flagged for review tomorrow.
[INCOMING WARD NURSE]: Got it. I’ll continue monitoring his BGLs, ketones, and electrolytes, and keep him on protocol.
[OUTGOING ED NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if he deteriorates or if there are any concerns with fluid balance. All documentation is up to date, including fluid balance chart and DKA pathway.

example.text:
[OUTGOING ED NURSE]: Hi, i'm handing over bed 4, Ms. Aisha Patel, 34 years old. She’s presented to ED with acute gastroenteritis—onset was about 24 hours ago.
[INCOMING WARD NURSE]: Thanks. What are her main symptoms?
[OUTGOING ED NURSE]: Profuse watery diarrhoea—about 6 episodes in the last 12 hours—and 3 episodes of vomiting. No blood in stool. She’s had mild abdominal cramping and reports feeling dizzy when standing.
[INCOMING WARD NURSE]: What’s been done in ED?
[OUTGOING ED NURSE]: She’s been rehydrated with 2 litres of IV normal saline. Bloods were taken—U&Es show mild hypokalaemia, which we’ve started correcting. Stool sample has been sent. She’s afebrile, and vitals are now stable—BP 108/70, HR 92, afebrile, RR 18, SpO? 99% on room air.
[INCOMING WARD NURSE]: Any medications?
[OUTGOING ED NURSE]: Ondansetron 4 mg IV given with good effect. She’s tolerating sips of water now. No antibiotics charted at this stage—awaiting stool results. Electrolyte replacement is charted.
[INCOMING WARD NURSE]: Any comorbidities or allergies?
[OUTGOING ED NURSE]: No known medical history. No regular medications. NKDA.
[INCOMING WARD NURSE]: Any communication or social needs?
[OUTGOING ED NURSE]: English is her first language. Lives alone, works as a teacher. She’s a bit embarrassed about the symptoms but otherwise coping well. Prefers a female nurse if possible.
[INCOMING WAR DNURSE]: Got it. I’ll continue fluids, monitor output, and keep an eye on her electrolytes.
[OUTGOING ED NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if she deteriorates or becomes febrile. All documentation is up to date, including fluid balance and stool chart.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, I'm handing over bed 11, Mr. Thomas Nguyen, 64 years old. He’s been admitted with multiple left-sided rib fractures—ribs 5 through 8—after a fall from a ladder yesterday.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Ouch. How’s he doing now?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s stable but in quite a bit of pain, especially with deep breathing and movement. He’s on regular paracetamol and oxycodone PRN. We’ve also started a fentanyl PCA overnight, which he’s using appropriately.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any respiratory concerns?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No signs of pneumothorax or haemothorax on imaging. Chest X-ray shows isolated rib fractures. He’s on 2 L nasal prongs to maintain sats above 94%. We’re encouraging deep breathing and coughing—he’s using the incentive spirometer.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any comorbidities?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hypertension and mild COPD. No known allergies. He’s a non-smoker now but has a 30-pack-year history.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Mobilising?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: With assistance. Physio reviewed this morning and will continue daily. He’s slow but safe with a frame. Needs supervision for toileting.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any communication or support needs?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: English is his first language. Lives with his wife. He’s a bit frustrated with the pain but very cooperative.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Got it. I’ll keep an eye on his pain and respiratory effort.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if his pain escalates or if there are any signs of respiratory compromise. All documentation is up to date, including pain scores and PCA charting.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, I'm John, handing over bed 2, Ms. Leila Haddad, 59 years old. She’s been admitted with a large pericardial effusion—likely secondary to metastatic breast cancer. She’s for pericardiocentesis this afternoon.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. How is she currently?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s haemodynamically stable but symptomatic—short of breath at rest, mild chest tightness, and fatigue. No syncope or hypotension. She’s on 2 L nasal prongs to maintain sats around 94%.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: What’s been done so far?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s had an urgent echo showing a large effusion with early signs of tamponade. Cardiology has reviewed and booked her for ultrasound-guided pericardiocentesis this afternoon. Consent is done.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: IV access?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Two good IVs—one 18G in the left AC and a 20G in the right forearm. Both patent. She’s on maintenance IV fluids—normal saline at 75 mL/hr.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Medications?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s had IV dexamethasone 8 mg this morning and regular paracetamol for discomfort. PRN midazolam is charted for the procedure. No anticoagulants on board. NKDA.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Observations?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: BP 102/68, HR 98, RR 22, SpO? 94% on 2 L, Temp 36.8. She’s alert and oriented but anxious. ECG shows low voltage QRS, no arrhythmias.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any support needs?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: English is her second language—Arabic is her first. She understands most things but prefers slow explanations. Her daughter is bilingual and has been helping. Interpreter has been requested for post-procedure education.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Got it. I’ll keep monitoring her obs closely and prep her for the drain.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if she deteriorates—especially signs of tamponade like hypotension or muffled heart sounds. All documentation is up to date, including consent, obs, and fluid balance.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over bed 5, Ms. Carol Tan, 72 years old. She was admitted for a permanent pacemaker insertion due to symptomatic bradycardia. The procedure was done this morning, but she’s developed a left-sided pneumothorax post-op.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Oh no—how was it picked up?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She became short of breath and desaturated to 89% on room air about an hour post-procedure. Chest X-ray confirmed a moderate pneumothorax. The cardiology team has reviewed, and a chest drain has been inserted—left side, mid-axillary line.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: How is she now?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: More comfortable. She’s on 2 L nasal prongs—sats are now 96%. Drain is on low suction and swinging well. No signs of tension. Vitals are stable—BP 122/70, HR 78 (paced), RR 20, Temp 36.7.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: IV access?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: One 20G in the right forearm—patent. She’s on maintenance IV fluids—normal saline at 75 mL/hr. No IV antibiotics charted at this stage.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Medications?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Regular meds include metoprolol, atorvastatin, and aspirin. She’s had paracetamol for mild post-op pain. No known allergies. Analgesia and PRNs are charted.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any other concerns?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s a bit anxious and tearful—understandably shaken by the complication. English is her first language. She’s continent and mobilising with assistance. Physio has been informed for post-drain mobility review.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Got it. I’ll monitor the drain, pain, and oxygen needs closely.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. Let the team know if there’s any increase in respiratory distress or if the drain output changes significantly. All documentation is up to date, including drain chart, obs, and post-op notes.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over bed 10, this is Mrs. Joan Murphy, 73 years old. Joan, this is Nurse Alex, who’ll be looking after you this afternoon.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Joan, nice to meet you. I’ll be taking over your care now. How are you feeling?
[PATIENT]: Still a bit breathless, but better than this morning.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Joan came in overnight with an acute exacerbation of COPD—increased shortness of breath, wheeze, and productive cough. She’s now on IV ceftriaxone and IV hydrocortisone, both charted for 3 days. She’s also on salbutamol and ipratropium nebs Q4H.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Got it. What’s her oxygen requirement?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s on 2 L via nasal prongs to keep sats between 88–92%—that’s her target range. She desats quickly if off oxygen. Her Q-ADDS score was 4 earlier due to increased RR and oxygen requirement, so she’s on 2-hourly observations.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any recent changes?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s improving slowly. RR is down to 22, sats 91% on 2 L, HR 96, BP 134/78, Temp 37.4. She’s afebrile now. We’ve started a fluid balance chart—she’s on IV fluids at 75 mL/hr due to poor oral intake. Strict input/output is being monitored.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any comorbidities?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes—hypertension and osteoporosis. No known drug allergies. She’s normally independent at home but has needed assistance with ADLs today due to fatigue.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Joan, are you managing okay with meals and drinks?
[PATIENT]: Not really hungry, but I’ve had some soup and water.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: That’s okay—we’ll keep encouraging fluids and monitor your intake.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s also on a respiratory chart—we’re tracking sputum colour, volume, and work of breathing. Physio has been to see her and will review again tomorrow.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Joan, I’ll check your obs shortly and make sure your breathing stays comfortable. Let me know if you feel more breathless or unwell.
[PATIENT]: Will do. Thank you both.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: All documentation is up to date—Q-ADDS, fluid balance, and respiratory charting. Let the team know if her Q-ADDS score increases or if she deteriorates.

example.text:
[WARD_NURSE]: Hi, thanks for coming to see Mr. Alan Brooks in bed 12. He’s Day 1 post-CABG, just transferred from ICU this morning. He’s stable but still has several attachments in place, so we’ll need to be cautious with mobility.
[PHYSIOTHERAPIST]: Can you give me a quick overview?
[WARD_NURSE]: Sure. He had a triple vessel CABG yesterday. He’s currently on: IV dopamine, weaning at 0.05 mcg/kg/min, currently running at 3 mcg/min, he has a CVL in the right internal jugular, there are Three chest drains still in situ. He has an IDC draining clear urine, Telemetry monitoring active. 
[PHYSIOTHERAPIST]: Okay. Is he alert and able to follow instructions?
[WARD_NURSE]: Yes, he’s alert, orientated, and cooperative. Pain is well-managed with paracetamol and PRN oxycodone. He’s keen to mobilise but understandably anxious.
[PHYSIOTHERAPIST]: Any precautions I should be aware of?
[WARD_NURSE]: Yes—sternal precautions apply. No pushing or pulling with arms, no lifting above shoulder height. We’ll need to support the chest drains and CVL during movement. IDC can be secured to the leg.
[PHYSIOTHERAPIST]: Any recent obs or concerns?
[WARD_NURSE]:
Vitals are stable: BP: 104/68, HR: 88 bpm, sinus rhythm, SpO?: 96% on room air
No dizziness or desaturation noted. He’s due for obs in 30 minutes.
[PHYSIOTHERAPIST]: I’ll start with a gentle sit-out and breathing exercises and reassess tolerance. I’ll liaise with the team about progressing mobility tomorrow.
[WARD_NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if you need help with attachments or if anything changes.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, I'm  handing over bed 14, this is Ms. Emily Dawson, 67 years old. Emily, this is Nurse Priya, who’ll be looking after you this evening.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Emily, nice to meet you. I’ll be taking over your care now. How are you feeling?
[PATIENT]: A bit sore, but okay. Just tired.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Emily came in this morning after a fall at home—she tripped over a rug and landed on her outstretched left arm. X-rays confirmed a closed fracture of the left distal radius. It’s been immobilised in a backslab, and ortho has reviewed—she’s for conservative management at this stage.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Got it. Any pain relief?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes—she’s had regular paracetamol and one dose of oxycodone 5 mg earlier this afternoon. Pain is currently 3 out of 10, and she’s tolerating it well. PRNs are charted.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any IV access?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No IV needed—she’s on oral meds only. Vitals have been stable all shift—BP 132/76, HR 78, afebrile, SpO? 98% on room air.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Emily, are you managing okay with eating, drinking, and getting around?
[PATIENT]: Yes, I can manage with my right hand. I just need help getting to the bathroom.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s mobilising with supervision. No dizziness or unsteadiness, but we’ve kept her on assisted walks just in case. OT and physio have been referred for tomorrow.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any allergies or other medical issues?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No known drug allergies. Medical history includes hypertension and osteoarthritis. She’s on amlodipine and takes Panadol Osteo regularly at home.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Emily, I’ll check in on your pain and help you settle in for the evening. If you need anything, just press the call bell.
[PATIENT]: Thank you both. I appreciate it.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: All documentation is up to date, including neurovascular checks and pain scores. Let me know if anything changes.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. James Daniels, 58 years old. James, this is Nurse Sarah, who’ll be looking after you this afternoon.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi James, I’ll be your nurse for the next shift. How are you feeling?
[PATIENT]: Bloated and uncomfortable. It’s hard to breathe when I lie flat.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: James has decompensated liver disease from long-term alcohol use. He’s been admitted with tense ascites—his abdomen is distended and uncomfortable, and he’s short of breath. He’s for a therapeutic paracentesis this afternoon.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. Has he been consented?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, the medical team has reviewed and consented him. Ultrasound has confirmed large-volume ascites. He’s been fasted, and we’ve inserted a 20G IV in the right forearm—patent and flushed.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any medications?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s on IV albumin post-drain as per protocol, and oral spironolactone and frusemide. No antibiotics charted yet—awaiting fluid culture results. No known allergies.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Fluid balance?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s on a strict fluid balance chart. We’ve started daily weights and abdominal girth measurements. He’s mildly hypotensive—BP 94/60, HR 88, RR 20, SpO? 96% on room air. Temp 36.9. He’s on Q-ADDS—scoring 3 due to low BP, so we’re doing 4-hourly observations.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any support needs?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: English is his first language. He’s alert and oriented but anxious about the procedure. He’s been open about his alcohol use and is willing to engage with support services. Social work and AOD team have been referred.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Got it. James, I’ll check your obs and help you get comfortable before the procedure. Let me know if you feel dizzy or more bloated.
[PATIENT]: Thanks. I just want this fluid out.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: All documentation is up to date—fluid chart, Q-ADDS, and med chart. Let the team know if his BP drops further or if there are signs of infection post-drain.

example.text:
[NIGHT_NURSE]: Morning. Handing over Mrs. Evelyn Taylor, 81 years old, in bed 7. Evelyn, this is Nurse Mia, who’ll be looking after you today.
[MORNING_NURSE]: Hi Evelyn, I’ll be your nurse this morning. How are you feeling?
[PATIENT]: I feel a bit strange. My right arm feels heavy, and I’m having trouble speaking clearly.
[NIGHT_NURSE]: That’s actually new. She was drowsy overnight, but I thought it was just fatigue. I didn’t notice any clear deficits during the night, but she’s now showing slurred speech and right-sided weakness. I’ve just done a quick neuro check—there’s a facial droop and reduced grip on the right.
[MORNING_NURSE]: That sounds like a possible stroke. Has the doctor been notified?
[NIGHT_NURSE]: Not yet—I picked it up just before handover. I was about to escalate. She’s on Q-ADDS, scoring 6 now—due to new neuro changes and slightly elevated BP (162/94). HR 84, RR 18, SpO? 97% on room air, Temp 36.6.
[MORNING_NURSE]: Okay, I’ll call the medical registrar immediately and start hourly neuro obs.
[DOCTOR]: (enters) I’ve just been informed. Evelyn, I’m Dr. Singh. We’re concerned you may have had a stroke overnight, and we’re going to do some urgent tests, including a CT scan.
[PATIENT]: Oh… I didn’t realise. I just thought I was tired.
[DOCTOR]: You did the right thing by speaking up. We’ll take care of you.
[MORNING_NURSE]: I’ll stay with her and start the neuro obs now. Is she nil by mouth?
[DOCTOR]: Yes, keep her NPO until we assess her swallow. I’ll organise an urgent stroke team review.
[NIGHT_NURSE]: She’s on a fluid balance chart, and her oral intake was minimal overnight. No IV fluids running yet. She’s on regular antihypertensives and aspirin. No known allergies.
[MORNING_NURSE]: Got it. I’ll update the family once we have a clearer picture.
[NIGHT_NURSE]: Thanks. All documentation is up to date—Q-ADDS, med chart, and fluid balance.

example.text:
[ED NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Mrs. Anna Lewis, 35 years old, being transferred to the surgical ward. Anna, this is Nurse Claire, who’ll be looking after you now. Mark, you’re welcome to stay with her as long as you need.
[WARD NURSE]: Hi Anna, hi Mark. I’m really sorry you’re going through this. I’ll do everything I can to make you comfortable and supported.
[PATIENT]: Thank you. I’m still trying to process everything.
[ED NURSE]: Anna presented to ED overnight with vaginal bleeding and cramping at 10 weeks gestation. An ultrasound confirmed no fetal heartbeat. She’s been reviewed by O&G and is for a D&C later today.
[WARD NURSE]: I’m so sorry, Anna. We’ll make sure you’re cared for gently. Have you had anything to eat or drink?
[PATIENT]: No, I haven’t eaten since yesterday evening.
[ED NURSE]: She’s been kept Nil by mouth since 2:00 AM. Vitals are stable—BP 110/70, HR 84, afebrile. She’s had paracetamol and a single dose of IV fluids. No allergies. She has a 20G IV in the left forearm, patent and flushed.
[WARD NURSE]: Any medications charted?
[ED NURSE]: Just analgesia and PRNs. No antibiotics yet. She’s on a fluid balance chart, and we’ve started Q-ADDS—currently scoring 1. She’s understandably tearful but oriented and engaging.
[DOCTOR]: (enters) Anna, I’m Dr. Nguyen from the surgical team. I’m very sorry for your loss. We’ll be performing a D&C this afternoon to help manage the bleeding and support your recovery. We’ll talk you through everything and answer any questions.
[PATIENT]: Will I be asleep for it?
[DOCTOR]: Yes, you’ll be under a light general anaesthetic. It’s a short procedure, and we’ll monitor you closely afterward.
[HUSBAND]: Can I stay with her until she goes to theatre?
[WARD NURSE]: Absolutely. We’ll make sure you’re both supported. I’ll also check in with the social worker and pastoral care team if you’d like someone to talk to.
[ED NURSE]: All documentation is up to date—fluid chart, Q-ADDS, and consent form. Please let the team know if her bleeding increases or if she becomes more distressed.

[WARD NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Mrs. Evelyn Grant, 87 years old, being transferred to the transit lounge to await transport back to her nursing home. Evelyn, this is Nurse Tom, who’ll be looking after you until your transport arrives.
[TRANSIT LOUNGE NURSE]: Hi Evelyn, lovely to meet you. We’ll make sure you’re comfortable while you wait.
[WARD NURSE]: Evelyn was admitted five days ago with aspiration pneumonia. She’s responded well to IV antibiotics and supportive care. She’s now afebrile, respiratory rate is 18, SpO? 96% on room air, and she’s mobilising short distances with assistance.
[TRANSIT LOUNGE NURSE]: Great. Any swallowing concerns?
[WARD NURSE]: Yes, she has known dysphagia—thickened fluids and minced moist diet. She’s been reviewed by speech pathology and is safe to resume her usual nursing home diet plan. No signs of aspiration since admission.
[TRANSIT LOUNGE NURSE]: Okay. Any medications due?
[WARD NURSE]: No meds due during transit. She’s had her morning meds—oral antibiotics completed yesterday. No allergies. She has a 22G IV in the left hand, but it can be removed before discharge.
[TRANSIT LOUNGE NURSE]: Any behavioural concerns?
[WARD NURSE]: No. She’s pleasant, a bit confused at times but reorients easily. Nursing home staff are aware and familiar with her baseline.
[TRANSIT LOUNGE NURSE]: Got it. Is transport booked?
[WARD NURSE]: Yes, booked for 11:30 AM. All discharge paperwork is complete, including medication summary and nursing home handover form. Please let the team know if there’s any delay or change in her condition.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Cindy. I’m Alex, I’ll be looking after you today. Is it okay if we do your bedside handover with Sam before he finishes?
[PATIENT]: Yes, that’s fine.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: This is Bed 1, Cindy Benedictos, under Dr. Smith. She came in for management of diabetes and high cholesterol.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: How high did her blood sugars Go? what was her cholesterol level?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: The blood sugars were running at 14-16mmol and her cholesterol level is 7.4 so both high. She was seen by the team today and they adjusted her insulin doses again—details are in the chart, and she has been started on a statin. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, I’ll review the med chart after handover.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Because Her BGLs have been fluctuating. We’re doing QID plus PRN levels.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Are there any significant highs or lows noted?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Variable but the insulin is helping to bring the level down it has been documented on the BGL sheet.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s on daily bloods. The diabetes educator is booked for tomorrow at 2:30 p.m.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Have today’s bloods been sent?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, taken and sent this morning we are still waiting for the results.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Cindy is self-caring—she self-administers her insulin with a little supervision.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Perfect. Cindy, are you comfortable continuing to do your insulin with me double-checking?
[PATIENT]: Yes, that’s what I’ve been doing.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. Any allergies we should be aware of?
[PATIENT]: I'm allergic to penicillin.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: The team is planning to discharge her early next week.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll keep an eye on the plan and diabetes educator's notes.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Otherwise, all her observations have been within normal limits.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: okay great. Anything else outstanding?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: We still need to send a urine test off, the form is in her chart.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Sam. Cindy, I’ll come back shortly to check your next BGL and see if you need anything before breakfast.
[PATIENT]: Thanks.

[INCOMING_NURSE] Hi Thomas. Shall we start at Bed 1?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yep. Bed 1 is Ramanathan Nishapilai, under Dr. Smith.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi Ramanathan, this is Thomas, the day nurse taking over from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Ramanathan. Can you please confirm your full name?
[PATIENT]: Ramanathan Nishapilai.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’m checking your ID band now the details match. I'm just going to check your medication charts and your IV cannula to make sure they are correct. Do you have any allergies we should know about?
[PATIENT]: No known drug allergies.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. And what pronouns do you prefer?
[PATIENT]: He/him.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks—apologies if I misspoke earlier.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Ramanathan is 46 years old, admitted under Dr. Smith with a two-week history of arrhythmia. He has a prior history of the same issue and is here for management.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s on the same medication regimen as previously; nothing new added and no changes overnight. There’s no plan for discharge yet.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Has he had any issues overnight such as chest pain, dizziness, palpitations?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No he hasn't mentioned anything to me. He’s been stable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Ramanathan, anything you’d like to add or anything you need right now?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m okay, thanks.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: All right, we’ll continue with your current management and I’ll check in regularly. Use the call bell if you need me.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Ramanathan. I’ll leave you with Thomas.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks for the handover.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Bed 5 is Layla Sonia Da Silva. Layla, this is George who is the day nurse and will be looking after you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi, Layla. We’ll do a quick bedside handover with you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Could you tell us your full name, just to confirm who you are.
[PATIENT]: Layla Sonia Da Silva.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Layla. So, Layla is 34 years old, admitted under Dr. Liu for management of her diabetes.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Her past history is: type 1 diabetes since childhood and hypertension.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s independent and ambulant on the ward, she is self-caring with her own blood glucose checks and insulin.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Layla, are you comfortable checking your BGLs and giving your insulin yourself?
[PATIENT]: Yes, I’ve been doing it for a long time.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Her insulin is on a sliding scale/variable dose. We confirm each dose with the doctor based on her current BGL.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Her morning sugars have been trending high, so the team still needs to review and possibly adjust the regimen.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Her Blood pressure has been in the high-normal range around 140/84; also for team review.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s still for a referral to the diabetes educator.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: There are no other problems noted.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, I will 
- Touch base with the team about the morning highs and her BP.
- Clarify the next insulin dose with the doctor.
- Follow up the diabetic educator referral and see when they are coming.
- Continue to document her BGLs and insulin administration. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Layla, is there anything you need right now or anything you’d like to add?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m okay. Thanks.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. We’ll check in again after I speak with the team.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Morning, Pierre. I’m John the oncoming nurse for the day. I’ll just grab a quick bedside handover from Susan if that’s okay?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: This is bed 2, Pierre Cox, who is 77 years old, under Dr Greger.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi, Pierre. Could you confirm your full name for me?
[PATIENT]: Pierre Cox.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Pierre came in with pain and swelling of the right leg, query an embolism. He’s for a leg ultrasound today at 2 p.m. He’s on therapeutic Clexane.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: How is his pain now?

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s still been quite sore—scored 9/10 earlier; Endone was given with good effect. He’s charted for regular OxyContin and Panadol, and he can have PRN analgesia as needed.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Pierre, how’s your pain right now—still high, or a bit better since the Endone?
[PATIENT]: A bit better, but still there.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, we’ll stay on top of it and use the PRN if you need it.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He needs assistance with transfers with 2 people. He’s using a commode chair to get to the toilet and is unable to walk at the moment due to the leg pain.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: We need to assist with all his transfers, Pierre—just press your call bell when you need to go to the toilet.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: His obs have been normal overall with a slightly raised blood pressure—likely pain-related. The doctors are aware that it is high.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay ill keep an eye on it. 

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s on a low‑fat diet.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Has his meal been ordered today?

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes. He’s still for review by the team; the consultant hasn’t seen him yet.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll keep an eye out for the team and update you after they come, Pierre.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He has Coronary artery disease; and is a heavy smoker. We’ve started a nicotine patch, but he really doesn’t like it. He’s asked to go outside to smoke—he’s been advised not to.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Pierre, hospital policy is no smoking on site. Let’s talk about managing the cravings—if the patch isn’t suiting you, we can discuss alternatives with the team.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Any thing I've missed? 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: No Thanks. I'll keep up with pain management meds and give PRN meds if needed.
[PATIENT]: Okay, thank you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Anything you need before we go, Pierre?
[PATIENT]: I’m all right for now.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great—I’ll be back shortly to check your pain and get you set for the ultrasound.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Eric. This is Sam, the day nurse taking over from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi, Eric. We’ll do your handover together at the bedside.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Bed eight is Eric Wong, he is 69 years old, under Dr Johnson.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s come in for management of high cholesterol. The Plan is for daily bloods and a carotid Doppler ultrasound tomorrow.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s also booked for an arterial/vascular study so they can start his medication.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. Do we have times yet?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No they are not confirmed yet. He’s quite anxious about the tests.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Could we get the medical team to come and explain the procedure to him today?
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Absolutely—I’ll page Dr Johnson’s team to talk you through everything, Eric.
[PATIENT]: Thanks, I’m just a bit worried about what it involves.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Totally understandable. We’ll make sure someone explains it clearly and answers your questions before anything happens.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s on a general diet, ambulant, and self-caring.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: History of high blood pressure; otherwise observations have been stable. The team is aware.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. I’ll keep monitoring your BP and we’ll get today’s bloods done as ordered.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Eric, is there anything you need right now?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m okay. Thank you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: All right, I’ll follow up with the doctors and come back with an update.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me. Thanks, Eric.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Rebecca. I’m Mia, I’ll be looking after you today. I’m just going to get handover from Alex, is that okay?
[PATIENT]: Sure.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Mia. This is Rebecca Burks who is a 54 year old, under Dr Dalianis.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Rebecca. Can you please tell me your full name and date of birth?
[PATIENT]: Rebecca Burks, and it’s the 14th of May, 1970.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you. Any allergies we need to know about?
[PATIENT]: None that I’m aware of.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Presentation was dizziness, weakness, tachycardia and nausea. She’s diagnosed with ischaemic heart disease, with a history of atherosclerosis and breast cancer.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: How are you feeling right now, Rebecca?
[PATIENT]: Still a bit weak and a little queasy, but better than yesterday.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s otherwise stable today. The patient is self-caring and ambulant, but she needs a little supervision when walking—so one assist because of the weakness.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: We’ll make sure someone walks with you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s on regular anti-emetics before meals for her nausea, and she’s also got regular pain relief charted.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll check when the next anti-emetic is due before breakfast.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Observations are visible on the station screens, but they still need to be written into the obs chart each round.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: We need to do a ECG printout at the start of each shift, and any time there’s an abnormality. we put the printouts in her chart.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Rebecca I’ll do a baseline ECG after handover so we have it for this shift.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: The blood pressure needs to be done on her right arm due to her right-sided mastectomy.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks for the reminder. I’ll use the left arm only and pop a “no BP right arm” sign if it’s not already up.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Doctors are around frequently, so we can check anything with them as needed.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Rebecca, we’ll help you up with one person and keep your call bell close. Anything you need before we go?
[PATIENT]: Could I have some water, please?
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Of course—I’ll bring that in with your meds. Plan for the shift: baseline ECG and file, regular obs documented in the chart, anti-emetic before meals, pain relief as needed, supervise mobilising with one assist, and BP on the left arm only.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me.
[PATIENT]: Thank you both.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Frank. I’m the day nurse coming on now my name is Henry. I’ll get a quick handover from Arthur at the bedside if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi. This is bed 5, Frank Morgan Montgomery. Frank, this is the incoming nurse who’ll be looking after you today.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Frank—could you tell me your full name and date of birth.
[PATIENT]: Frank Morgan Montgomery, 25 October 1947.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Frank is 78 years old and under Dr. Sanchez. He came in with shortness of breath and tiredness post‑op. He has a history of CABG eight years ago. We’ve noted a decreasing level of consciousness, so neuro observations are being done QID. He was tachy this morning—post‑op—and he’s on oxygen at 3 liters via nasal prongs. His oxygen saturations are all good now. He’s here for further monitoring.
[INCOMING_NURSE]:  Has there been any changes to his LOC since earlier?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He's a little drowsy compared to baseline but rousable; no acute deterioration since last my last round.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, I’ll keep a close eye and escalate if there’s any decline. Frank, how’s your breathing feeling right now?
[PATIENT]: Better than before, just a bit tired.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: All right. We’ll continue monitoring your heart rate, breathing, and level of alertness. If you feel more short of breath or more drowsy, please let us know.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Anything else outstanding—bloods, scans, or new orders?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No new orders noted; just ongoing monitoring.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Perfect. I’ll check your vitals shortly, Frank, and make sure you’re comfortable. Do you need anything before we finish handover?
[PATIENT]: No, thank you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: All right, Frank. I’m heading off now. You’re in good hands.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll be back in a moment to recheck your observations.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, Lucila. I’m the day nurse coming on. We’ll do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Morning. This is bed 6, Ms. Lucila Marlor, 88 years old, who is under Dr. Sanchez.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Ms. Marlor. We’re just talking about you so we can plan your care today.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Lucila was admitted five days ago with a suspected overdose. She lives in a retirement facility. She’s been improving since admission.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, Any change in how much help she needs?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She needs minimal assistance with ADLs—same as previously noted.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: so she's minimal assist with activities of daily living? 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Ms. Marlor, does that sound right to you just need a little help with things like washing, dressing, and getting around?
[PATIENT]: Yes, that’s right. I just need a hand sometimes.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: No worries, we’ll make sure you’ve got the help you need.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any other issues overnight?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No new issues reported. She is continuing to improve.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Is there a plan for today?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: To continue current care, assist with ADLs as needed, and await Dr. Sanchez’s review.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Perfect. Ms. Marlor, we’ll check on you regularly. Use your call bell if you need anything between visits.
[PATIENT]: Thank you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks for the handover.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Mindy, could you confirm your full name for us?
[PATIENT]: Mindy Jasmine Parks.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you. I’ve checked your wristband—details match the chart and you have had all your medications for now. 

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Mindy has recurrent lung cancer with chest pain and a cough. She had lung cancer five years ago. she was also a heavy smoker for about 10 years.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. Is she still smoking or has she given up?

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She has given up. She had bloods taken this morning and I haven’t checked if the results are back yet. From the doctors’ ward round, my understanding is they weren’t great, but I don’t have the specifics. This will need to be  followed-up.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: No Problem, I’ll chase the blood results and review the notes/orders after this.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Her family is in attendance.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Her observations were stable for my whole shift so QADDS equals zero.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Is she on  any oxygen or telemetry?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No, just routine monitoring. She’s for further monitoring today.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No nothing at the moment.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything I need to tell you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Alex.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Amanda. I’m Dorothy the day nurse. I’ll just get handover from Oliver, then we’ll check in with you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi Dorothy. In Bed 3 is Amanda Agatha Phillips, who is 76 years old.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Amanda, can you tell us your full name and date of birth?
[PATIENT]: I… I’m not sure… sorry.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: That’s okay, I’ll check your wristband. Amanda Agatha Phillips, 76. Thanks.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]:She has a history of sleep apnoea; she uses home oxygen at night only.
[INCOMING_NURSE] Does she use nasal prongs or a mask?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: A Mask. She has come in for further investigation. Her family are quite worried about her living alone, so she needs a referral to Social Work.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: okay, I’ll put the referral to the Social Worker this morning.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s been very confused. Yesterday she couldn’t remember her relatives when they visited and She’s still confused today, so there is no change in her level of confusion.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, so this is her base line.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, There’s also a query for a … “cut” assessment and a mini-mental assessment for Tim to review.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Do you mean an ACAT assessment plus a Mini-Mental (MMSE) for Tim?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, that’s the request—ACAT and MMSE for Tim to review.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Got it. I’ll organise the MMSE and flag ACAT with Social Work, and I’ll message Tim.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Otherwise, no other changes. She is still confused.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Amanda, we’re going to keep you safe and comfortable. If you need anything, press the call bell here.
[PATIENT]: I… where am I?
[INCOMING_NURSE]: You’re in hospital, Amanda. We’re looking after you. We’ll stay close by. Don't get up and walk on your own as I don't want you to fall.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Anything else you’d like me to cover?
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll set up the referrals now and keep an eye on her orientation and night oxygen needs.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Great. Thanks.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Amanda. I’ll be back shortly.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Nina. This is the day nurse who’ll be looking after you now. Is it okay if we do your bedside handover together?
[PATIENT]: Yes, that’s fine.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Nina. Good morning. I’m the incoming nurse for the day my name is Hannah

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: This is Bed 1, Nina Maria Carey, who is67 years old, under Dr Jamie. She came in with bronchitis, fever, and cough. She’s also just been diagnosed with cancer, and we’ve been told it has already spread to the lungs. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’m sorry you’re going through that, Nina. We’ll make sure you have the support you need.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Her observations are stable and she’s afebrile. She’s self-caring and on a general diet. No other concerns raised overnight.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, No IV lines at present?

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No she hasn't the need for one at the moment.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Nina, part of today’s plan is communication and support. The notes say your husband and your four children should be informed.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: With your permission, who would you like us to update them on your progress, how can we reach them?
[PATIENT]: Please contact my husband first, then we can decide about the kids together.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Of course. We’ll follow your preferences and only share information with your consent.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: We can also arrange counselling if you’d like, and set up a meeting with the doctors to go through your treatment plan and answer questions.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Would you like me to organize counselling and a family meeting with Dr Jamie’s team today?
[PATIENT]: Yes, I’d appreciate that.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: The plan for today is to continue routine observations, have a normal diet, stay independent cares as you feel able. We need to confirm and document your preferred contacts; arrange counselling and a family meeting with Dr Jamie. Anything else you need right now, Nina?
[PATIENT]: No, thank you.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s all I need to tell you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll get started on those referrals and be back shortly to check on you again, Nina.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Good Morning. Let’s do bedside handover for Bed 2.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi Rob, this is Sam, the day nurse taking over from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Rob. I’ll just do a quick handover with Jess, and then we’ll get you sorted for going home.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Could you confirm your full name for me?
[PATIENT]: Rob Mahi.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Rob.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: This is Bed 2, Rob Mahi, 62 years old, under Dr Jamie.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He came in for an allergy test and asthma experiments, and he’s also here for physio input.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: His Past history is asthma and multiple allergies.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He developed a rash from the allergy test yesterday and wasn’t happy about that.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Rob, are you still itchy or uncomfortable now?
[PATIENT]: It’s a lot better today, just a bit sensitive.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, we can get you some soothing cream if needed.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Physiotherapy reviewed him and they recommended an adjustment to his asthma medications.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s for discharge today. The discharge paperwork is completed; he’s just waiting for his medications from the pharmacy.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. Do we know what time pharmacy will send them up?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: They’ve been notified, so it should be soon. Everything else for the discharge is done.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Rob, once the tablets arrive, I’ll go through them with you and the medication changes physio suggested. How are you getting home?
[PATIENT]: Okay Sounds good. I’ll call a taxi once the medications are here.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any breathing issues at the moment? Wheeze or shortness of breath?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m okay now.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Anything else outstanding, Jess?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: IV cannulas have been removed, we are Just waiting on the meds from pharmacy and he’s clear to leave.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Perfect. Rob, do you have any questions before Jess heads off?
[PATIENT]: No, just keen to get my tablets and go.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: We’ll chase pharmacy now. Thanks, Jess.

[PATIENT]: Sure.

[PATIENT]: Alistair Edwards.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you. And any allergies?
[PATIENT]: Peanuts.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, a known peanut allergy. He came in with an allergic reaction. He’s improving slowly; His throat is still a little bit swollen. He reports an itchy mouth and occasional difficulty breathing, but it’s been manageable. Otherwise he’s been okay.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Alistair, how’s your breathing right now—any tightness or wheeze?
[PATIENT]: It feels okay at the moment—just a bit of itch in my mouth.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: All right. If anything changes—more swelling, wheeze, or trouble breathing—please press the call bell straight away.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: His Vitals have been stable while I’ve been with him. and there are no new issues overnight.
[INCOMING_NURSE]:  We will continue to monitor your airway and level of comfort, Alistair.
[PATIENT]: Thanks.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Is there anything you need before we finish handover?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m good.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Great. I’ll hand over to you now.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll be back shortly to recheck you, Alistair.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Mr Hunt. I’m taking over your care now. We’ll just do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, okay?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks. This is Abraham Hunt, 83 years old, under Dr Jamie.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Mr Hunt, could you confirm your name for me?
[PATIENT]: Abraham Hunt.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you. Any medication allergies that you know of? and when was the cannula inserted?
[PATIENT]: No, not that I know of, it was put in yesterday in ED.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He presented with chest pain, but it’s more likely not cardiac-related. He does have a history of a heart attack five years ago.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any chest pain right now, Mr Hunt?
[PATIENT]: No, none at the moment.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any shortness of breath?
[PATIENT]: No.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s stable. On a general diet, self-caring and ambulant on the ward. He’s on his regular puffers and nebs.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Noted. Any IV lines?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No. Meds-wise, he’s also on Clexane daily.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: What’s the plan for today?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s awaiting the doctor’s review under and may need some follow up tests to see what is happening for you to come into hospital.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Mr Hunt, we’ll keep monitoring you. If that chest pain returns or anything changes, please press the call bell straight away.
[PATIENT]: Will do. Thank you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks for the handover. I’ll check your obs shortly and make sure your puffers and nebs are on schedule.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Good Morning. Bed 4 is Robert Lewis, but he prefers Bob.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Bob, I’m taking over your care now. Is it okay if we do handover at the bedside?
[PATIENT]: Sure.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Bob.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Bob is 62, under Dr. Johnson. He came in with a heart attack and has had a CABG.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any other medical history?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Notes say “high HD.” We’ll need to clarify whether that’s hypertension or hyperlipidaemia in the chart/with the team.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, I’ll confirm that in the notes.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s due for MRSA and VRE surveillance swabs.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll collect those this morning.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Ongoing surgical wound care—site looks clean and is healing well.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Bob, we’ll take a quick look later when we do your checks. Any pain at the wound site?
[PATIENT]: It’s okay, it's just a bit tender.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s been complaining of constipation— there has been no bowel movement for three days. Regular aperients have been given with good effect; he reports some relief.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, Bob, we’ll keep up the aperients and monitor for a bowel motion. Let us know if you feel any abdominal pain or nausea.
[PATIENT]: Will do.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: All observations are stable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. Any lines or drains?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No additional lines to note. Just routine post-op wound care.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Plan for today: collect MRSA/VRE swabs, continue surgical wound care, manage constipation, and routine obs. Anything else pending with Dr. Johnson?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: There are no other outstanding tasks from my end.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Bob, is there anything you need right now?
[PATIENT]: I’m okay, thanks.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Alright, I’ll be back shortly to do your checks and get those swabs done.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Good Morning. This is Mr. Helder Mendez, in bed 2. Hi Helder, we’re just doing your handover.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Mr. Mendez, I’m taking over your care this shift.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Helder is 76 years old, under Dr. Hutchins. He’s been admitted with recurrent lung cancer. He has a smoking history and COPD. He has had surgery, chemotherapy, and radiotherapy previously.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Gosh that's a lot of treatments.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s now on palliative care—comfort measures only. So no routine observations. We’re focusing on keeping him comfortable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Mr. Mendez, can you confirm your name for me?
[PATIENT]: Helder Mendez.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you. I’ll try and keep you pain free and comfortable.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s settled in bed, no other active interventions are planned. If anything changes symptom-wise in relation to pain, breathlessness, or anxiety we can give him the medications as charted, we are notify the team if we need anything more. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]:  I’ll check in regularly, to offer mouth care and reposition as you prefer as to keep you comfortable, Helder. Is there anything you need right now?
[PATIENT]: I’m okay, thank you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Bye helder.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll be nearby, Helder—use the call bell if you need anything.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, George. I’m the day nurse coming on. Do you mind if we do your bedside handover with Sam who’s just finishing up?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi George. We’ll keep it brief. Can you tell us your full name and date of birth, please?
[PATIENT]: George Belgin, 14-02-82.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, George. Any medication allergies?
[PATIENT]: No, no allergies that I know of.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Great. So, this is bed 6, George Belgin, 43 years old, under Dr McDonald. He was admitted for and has had a lung transplant, and he’s now suspected to have aspergillosis.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He had a chest X-ray today. He’s stable. No other changes to report for him.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Vitals have been within normal limits?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, observations stable. No acute issues during my shift. His QAADS is 2 for Respiration rate. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any new symptoms, George? Shortness of breath, fever, or chest pain?
[PATIENT]: A bit of a cough, but I feel okay. No chest pain.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Has there been no new issues overnight.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: So The Plan is to continue routine observations and await the medical team review with Dr McDonald?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]:  No.No other changes or pending tasks from nights.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Alright, George, if anything changes—breathlessness, pain, or you feel unwell—press the call bell. I’ll come back shortly to check your obs again.
[PATIENT]: Will do. Thanks.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, George. I’m heading off. You’re in good hands.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Sam. I’ll take it from here.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Good Morning. This is Bed 1, Chris McDonald, 21 years old, under Dr Kenzie. He was admitted with an infection in his lungs following a swimming accident.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Chris, I’m going to be your nurse today my name is Adam. Is it okay if we do your bedside handover?
[PATIENT]: Sure.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Could you tell me your full name, please?
[PATIENT]: Chris McDonald.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Chris. I’ll just confirm your date of birth on your ID band, check your IV cannula and that the medications have been given.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s currently on oxygen at 4 litres via simple face mask. No changes overnight; observations have remained stable his HR is 82 and BP of 124/76.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Chris, how’s your breathing feeling this morning—any chest pain or increased shortness of breath?
[PATIENT]: About the same. No chest pain.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Okay. He’s stable on the 4 litres of oxygen via a mask. There are no new orders from the team, Just regular pain relief, there are no other changes to report overnight. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. We’ll let Dr Kenzie’s team know if anything changes.
[PATIENT]: Okay, thank you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Is there anything you need right now—water, repositioning, or anything else?
[PATIENT]: I’m fine, thanks.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: All right, I’ll hand over care now. Thanks, Chris.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll be back shortly to recheck your obs and make sure you’re comfortable.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Morning. This is Bed 2.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hercules Kokinakis, he is 76, under Dr Kenzie.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Hercules, I’m the incoming nurse my name is Brad. We’re just doing your handover.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: He’s on a ventilator, so communication will be limited—Hercules, if you’re comfortable, give me a thumbs up?
[PATIENT]: Gives a small nod.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He was found by his wife on the floor at home, unconscious and not breathing so she rang the ambulance.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He has a past history of type 2 diabetes, sleep apnoea, and is overweight.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He is currently stable but ventilated, he needs regular position changes to prevent a pressure area.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any immediate concerns overnight?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No acute issues flagged. Monitoring ongoing while ventilated, his bp is 180/82 HR 56.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: What it is the plan for today? 
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Physio is to start next shift.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He is waiting for an ICU bed—transfer as soon as there’s a room available, this can be arranged sooner if he deteriorates, but he is currently stable.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay so physio will start on the next shift, and pending ICU bed. I’ll continue close monitoring and liaise with bed management.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hercules, we’ll keep you comfortable and keep you updated. If you’re in any pain, try to nod and we’ll assess.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me. Anything to add, Hercules?
[PATIENT]: Shakes head.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll take it from here.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Matt. I’m the day nurse coming on my name is Logan. I’ll just get handover from my colleague at your bedside, if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi Logan. This is Matt Owen, he is 43 years old, under Dr Kenzie. He’s one week post–lung transplant.
[INCOMING_NURSE]:  Matt, how are you feeling right now? Have you got any pain?
[PATIENT]: No I'm okay just A bit tired.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: The main issue at the moment is an infection which is slowing his recovery. He’s MRSA positive and on contact precautions.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I see the contact signage is up and we’ll use gowns and gloves.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He was on IV antibiotics; these have been changed to oral antibiotics now. He’s on his anti‑rejection medications as prescribed.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Are the oral antibiotics and immunosuppression all charted?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, all charted and given as scheduled.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Functionally, he’s self‑caring and ambulant. He showered independently this morning.
[INCOMING_NURSE]  Any issues with the shower?
[PATIENT]: No, all fine.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: The surgical wound is healing slowly. The wound nurse is coming this afternoon to assess his wound and do the dressing.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Do we have a time for the wound nurse?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No, they will just turn up. He’s on regular Endone and PRN morphine for his pain. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Matt, how’s your pain at the moment?
[PATIENT]: Manageable right now.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, just buzz if you need the PRN.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: All observations have been stable, and he hasn’t raised any other complaints.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Perfect. So plan the plan today is to continue oral antibiotics and anti‑rejection meds. The wound nurse review and do his dressing this afternoon, continue with regular obs, and give PRNs medication as needed.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s it from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Matt, anything else you need before I go check your meds?
[PATIENT]: I’m good, thanks.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great—I’ll be back shortly.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Candice. I’m Sam, I’ll be looking after you today. I’m just getting handover from Alex, the night nurse. Is that okay?
[PATIENT]: Sure.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: In bed 5 we have Candice Kosgay, 28 years old, under Dr Harrod. She came in with cystic fibrosis. There have been no changes overnight; the observations have been normal for her and she has a QADDS of 1 for respiration rate of 24.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay so there's been no changes overnight  and has a QADDS score of 1 for her resp rate. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Candice, can I just check your wristband to confirm your details?
[PATIENT]: Yes.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you—details match.Her IV cannula looks like it is oozing so I will change it sometime today.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any new symptoms since last night—breathlessness, chest pain, fever, or anything else?
[PATIENT]: No, nothing new. I feel the same.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s been stable and comfortable. No new orders from the team overnight.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. So the Plan is to continue your current care, routine observations, and we’ll touch base with Dr Harrod’s team on their round. Candice, if anything changes—more short of breath, chest feels tighter, or you need anything—please press the call bell.
[PATIENT]: Will do, thanks.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s all from me. Anything you need before I head off, Candice?
[PATIENT]: I’m fine, thanks.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. I’ll be back shortly to check your obs again.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Dave, I’m Jess, I’ll be looking after you today. I’m just getting handover from Sam who’s finishing the night shift. Is it okay if we talk through things at the bedside?
[PATIENT]: Yeah… okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Dave. So, this is Room 2, Bed 3: Dave McKenzie, 72 years old. He’s a new admission, arrived a few hours ago under Dr George De Silva with a background of dementia.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Dave, can you tell me your name?
[PATIENT]: Dave… McKenzie.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you, Dave. I’ll just check your ID band… all good.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: The Presenting issue is increasing confusion. They’re querying a UTI. He’s still for bloods and a urine MCS—I haven’t had a chance to do those yet. They’ve started him on oral antibiotics.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, so I need to do bloods and a urine MCS. I’ll get onto those this morning.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: His medical history includes CCF, hypertension, type 2 diabetes on oral hypoglycemics, and he has chronic back pain, in addition to the dementia.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s resting in bed at the moment. I haven’t seen him mobilise yet, so I’d suggest a physio referral. He’s also been refusing his meals, so a dietitian referral would be helpful.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll place referrals to physio and dietetics and reassess his intake.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: His observations have been stable since arrival. No other acute concerns noted.I have been watching him to make sure he doesn't go wandering off the ward.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. Any family updates?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s for nursing home placement; his wife has been informed about the admission.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Dave, we’re going to take some blood tests and a urine sample a bit later, and I’ll check in about food and how you’re feeling. Is there any pain right now?
[PATIENT]: My back’s okay… just tired.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: We’ll keep you comfortable.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me don't forget the bloods and urine sample, the antibiotics are due now. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Perfect. I’ll get started on those now. Dave, press your call bell if you need anything.
[PATIENT]: Okay.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s all from me, have a good shift.

[PATIENT]: No, I’m okay. Thank you.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Michelle. I’m the incoming nurse today, my name is Toby. We’ll just do a quick bedside handover with the night nurse if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Michelle. Could you please confirm your full name for us?
[PATIENT]: Michelle Morgan.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Okay, so Bed 1, is Michelle Morgan, who is 58 years old, under Dr. Fleming. She came in with headache and dizziness and is still under investigation.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: she’s on regular Panadol for pain. She has PRNs available if she needs them, they are oxycodone and morphine. She reported a headache a little while ago — I gave her PRN oxycodone with good effect.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, I’ll check when the next regular analgesia is due and keep an eye on her pain scores.
[PATIENT]: The headache is much better now, thank you.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Mobility-wise, she’s ambulant and mostly self-caring but needs a little supervision in case she feels dizzy when walking.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. Michelle, please buzz before you get up and we’ll walk with you.
[PATIENT]: Sure, I will.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Diet is general and she’s tolerating it well.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Observations have been stable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Perfect. I’ll do 4 hourly routine obs and neuro checks as per the unit protocol.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s it from me, see you tomorrow.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: So we will continue analgesia as charted, supervise your mobility, and wait for further investigations and instructions from Dr. Fleming’s team.
[PATIENT]: Sounds good.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Anything else you need right now, Michelle?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m okay. Thanks.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. Call if you feel dizzy or your headache returns. I’ll be back shortly.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning. Bed 2, Dylan Young?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes. Hi Dylan, this is the day nurse taking over his name is Tom. We’ll do your bedside handover now.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Dylan. I’ll speak clearly and take it slow. If you’d like to write or use signs, that’s fine.
[PATIENT]: [nods; holds up notepad]

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: So, Dylan Young, 41 years old, under Dr. Fleming. He’s an admission today with headaches, plus vision and speech problems.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He needs assistance when walking to the toilet because he can’t see properly. His communication is difficult to understand at times so he uses sign language or writes down what he wants. we need to Allow extra time for him to communicate.
[INCOMING_NURSE]:  We’ll keep the notepad and pen within reach so you can get it if you need it.
[PATIENT]: [gives thumbs up]

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s on a general diet and his Observations have all been normal.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any orders pending?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s for  bloods today.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll follow that up with pathology.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s on regular analgesia for pain. The Headaches are the main issue he's complaining about.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll check when the next dose is due and review pain scores.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Dylan, is there anything you need right now?
[PATIENT]: [writes: “No, thanks.”]
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. We’ll help you to the bathroom when you need to go—please use the call bell and wait for us so we can assist safely.
[PATIENT]: [nods]

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s all I need to tell you. Have a good shift.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll chase the bloods, continue regular obs and meds. 
[PATIENT]: [gives a small wave]

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning. Mind if I do bedside handover here in Bed 4?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Sure. Hi Andreas, this is Priya, she’ll be looking after you today.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Andreas. I’ll just listen in and then check a few things with you.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: So, Bed 4 is Andreas Melotov, 67, under Dr. Gordon, who was admitted with a head injury.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any key history?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: I haven’t had a chance to read his full history yet. I caught the medical team on their round earlier and they said to continue the antibiotics and current management.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, I’ll confirm the drug and next dose time on the med chart.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yep. Also, his… arms are all good—sorry, I mean his obs are all good. He’s stable and no other problems noted.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, his blood pressure looks good.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Andreas, how’s your head feeling at the moment, any headache, nausea, or dizziness?
[PATIENT]: Bit of a dull headache, but I’m okay.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll check what  pain relief you have written up.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Anything you need to do before you head off. 
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Just continue his antibiotics and routine monitoring. Nothing else has been flagged by the team.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. I’ll check the charts.
[PATIENT]: Okay, thank you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Andreas. I’ll head off. Priya’s got you now.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll be back in a moment to do your observations and make you comfortable.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning. I’m taking over Bed 5. Hi Yvonne, and hi there, Mum—I’m Tony. We’ll do a quick bedside handover with Heather, is that okay?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: This is Bed 5, who is Yvonne Matthews, she is26 years old, under Dr. Gordon. I’ve just checked her ID band—details and they match the chart.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great, thanks. Hi Yvonne—feel free to jump in if we miss anything.
[PATIENT]: Okay.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yvonne came in with a head injury sustained while playing basketball. The team are planning surgery, but we’re still waiting for the  results and for the surgeons to review her CT.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: So she still needs a surgical review of the CT before any final plan.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes. Her Observations have all been within normal limits, the BP is 112/76 and HR is 56 QADDS is Zero. She reported a headache today, so we gave some Endone  with a good effect.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Yvonne, how’s the headache now?
[PATIENT]: Better since the tablet, I'm just a bit worried.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I hear you. We’ll keep you updated as soon as we hear from the surgeons.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s self-caring and ambulant, with her mother in attendance. She’s very anxious and asking for frequent updates. Otherwise, she’s stable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll check when radiology and the surgical team are likely to review the CT and I’ll come back to let you both know.
[PATIENT]: Thank you.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Anything else outstanding?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No other issues noted.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: All her vitals look  good, I guees we will wait for the CT to be  reviewed to know the surgical plan. Yvonne, press the call bell if your headache worsens, you feel nauseous, dizzy, or anything changes.
[PATIENT]: I will.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll be back shortly after I touch base with the team.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Roger, I’m Sam, the day nurse. Is it okay if we do your bedside handover with Alex here?
[PATIENT]: Sure.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Roger. So, Bed 6 is Roger Thompson, he is 49 years old, under Dr Gordon. He arrived on the ward not long ago; I’ve completed his admission paperwork.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. What brought you in today, Roger?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He presented with nausea and dizziness. His Observations have been within normal limits since arrival.
[PATIENT]: I Still feel a little light-headed, but better than before.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He reported nausea on arrival; I gave ondansetron 4 mg sublingual with good effect.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Has that settled your stomach a bit?
[PATIENT]: Yeah, it helped.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s on a general diet. He hasn’t eaten much yet due to the nausea.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, we’ll keep it light and see how you go. Any IVs or special equipment?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No IV access required at present. He’s independent and self-caring; usually ambulant. He’s resting in bed now.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. I’ll recheck your obs shortly and see if you’re up to some fluids or toast.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: There's no other concerns at this stage.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Roger, anything you want to add or anything you need right now?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m okay. Just a bit tired.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: All right. So we will monitor your nausea and dizziness and give you your ondansetron which is due at 1630. We’ll let Dr Gordon’s team know if anything changes.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect, I'm heading off, see you tomorrow. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll be back shortly, Roger.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Kate. I’m the day nurse taking over, my name is Mildred. Is it okay if we do your bedside handover with you?
[PATIENT]: Yes, that’s fine.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]:  Bed 7. This is Kate Orange, who is 41 years old, under Dr. Lee. She came in after a car accident with a skull fracture and is now one week post brain surgery. She’s much better.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Any current concerns?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: her Head is not swollen, and there are no signs of any bleeding, and the surgical site is healing normally, which is good. Her Observations have been stable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any headache, dizziness, or nausea today?
[PATIENT]: No, I feel okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Antibiotics were IV yesterday; they’ve now been switched to oral and she’s continuing on orals today.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: oral antibiotics are due 1000. How’s her mobility?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s ambulant, short distances only around the ward. Self-caring with very minimal assistance.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Diet and fluids?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: General diet, tolerating well, normal fluids.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: So the Plan for today is to continue oral antibiotics, continue neuro observations, and do the wound/skin checks. Anything else outstanding?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No other problems noted.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Kate, is there anything you need right now or anything you’d like us to know?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m fine. Thank you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Perfect. We’ll check on you regularly and help with walks. Use your call bell if you need us.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: All yours. Thanks, Kate.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Lawrence. I’m Evie, taking over your care. I’ll just get a quick bedside handover from Jack, if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Evie. This is Bed 8, Lawrence Wong, who is 56 years old, under Dr Lee. He came in with a severe headache. He’s on regular analgesia and his observations have been stable. QADDS of zero. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Could you please confirm your full name and date of birth?
[PATIENT]: Lawrence Wong, and 25 December 1968.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you. Any allergies to medications?
[PATIENT]: No, none that I know of.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Overnight he reported a headache so  I gave him some Endone as charted, with good effect, there are no other issues noted.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Lawrence, how’s your head feeling now—any pain, nausea, or light sensitivity?
[PATIENT]: It’s okay at the moment—no nausea or light sensitivity.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: we will give you regular analgesia as charted.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes the Panadol is due at 1330. His Obs remain stable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Perfect. So the plans is we’ll continue regular analgesia, monitor your pain and observations, and let Dr Lee’s team know if anything changes. Lawrence, please buzz if the headache returns or gets worse.
[PATIENT]: Will do. Thank you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Anything else before Jack heads off?
[PATIENT]: I’m fine, thanks.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: All right, I’m off. Thanks, Lawrence.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Jack. I’ll be back shortly, Lawrence.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Sarah. I’m Jess, the day nurse. I’m going to get handover from Mark and then we’ll make a plan with you both. Hi there.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi Jess. Bed 4, Sarah Jeffries, 62, under Dr. Lane. Admitted with a head injury after a fall. Sarah’s husband is here at the bedside.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Sarah, could you confirm your full name for me while I check your ID band?
[PATIENT]: Sarah Jeffries.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi, Mr. Jeffries.
[SPOUSE]: Hi.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Overnight she’s been stable with no changes. She’s improving. We’re awaiting discharge planning once she’s fully recovered. Ongoing management of pain with medications and antibiotics, and she’s continuing with physio.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any new concerns overnight—nausea, dizziness, confusion?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No, none reported. Still the same and getting better.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Sarah, how’s your pain right now?
[PATIENT]: A bit sore, but manageable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, we’ll stay on top of that. I’ll check when your next dose is due. Mark, antibiotics ongoing as charted?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, continuing as charted. Physio is ongoing as well.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Perfect. I’ll touch base with physio about today’s session and with the team about discharge planning.
[SPOUSE]: Do you know when she might go home?
[INCOMING_NURSE]: The team will confirm after they review her and the discharge plan is finalized. We’ll keep you updated today.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Anything you want to add, Sarah?
[PATIENT]: No, that covers it.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: The Call bell is here within reach. We’ll keep your pain controlled, give antibiotics as prescribed, and coordinate physio and discharge planning. Anything you need before Mark heads off?
[PATIENT]: I’m okay, thank you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Sarah. I’ll leave you with Jess.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Mark. I’ll be back shortly with your pain meds and an update.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Good Morning. This is bed 6, Lisa Kerr, who is 62, under Dr Lane.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Lisa, I’m Evie, taking over your care now. Jack’s just going to give me the handover.
[PATIENT]: Okay… Where am I again?
[INCOMING_NURSE]: You’re in hospital, Lisa. You’re safe. Your husband’s on his way.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Lisa came in about three hours ago with a cerebral hemorrhage (apoplexy). Initial observations were taken and were within normal limits. She’s on neuro observations and currently scoring GCS 15. No weakness noted in either arm or leg.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: How often are the neuro obs? Has she had a CT head?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]:  hourly, She had a  CT brain which confirmed the hemorrhage. She’s on the emergency theatre list for brain surgery today. She’s been fasting since ED.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: So, NBM since 0930.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: We’re waiting for her husband to arrive to provide consent—he has power of attorney. Lisa’s confused and isn’t able to sign consent herself. She’s in a gown and the pre-op checklist is completed.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll keep her NBM, and liaise with theatres. I’ll contact the team once her husband arrives for consent.
[PATIENT]: Is my husband coming?
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Yes, he’s on his way, and we’ll update you both as soon as we have the surgery time.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any changes or concerns since arrival?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No acute changes—stable obs, remains confused but cooperative.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll stay close by, Lisa. Press the call bell if you need me.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Mary. I’m just handing over to Sam for the day shift, is that okay?
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Mary, I’m Sam. I’ll be looking after you today.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: We’re in room 1, bed 1. This is Mary Smith, 56, under Dr. Smith. Mary, could you confirm your full name and date of birth for us?
[PATIENT]: Mary Smith, 12th of March, 1968.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Mary.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Mary came in with shortness of breath on a background of acute on chronic renal failure, secondary to type 1 diabetes. She’s on a sliding scale insulin and self-administers her insulin.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Past history includes hypertension, osteoporosis, anaemia, and she has had a previous CVA.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She has a left AV fistula with a good bruit and thrill, and she’s on haemodialysis. She’s booked for dialysis this afternoon and needs the dialysis prescription for this afternoon.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Alex came in with back pain and fever, query urinary stones.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Cecilia, I’m Sam, I’ll be looking after you today. Is it okay if we do your handover at the bedside?
[PATIENT]: Yes, that’s fine.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: We’re in Bed 1, This is Cecilia Ramos, 38, under Dr Willow. Admitted with a renal obstruction; Her full history is in the notes.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll just check your ID band, Cecilia… great, thank you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She had a CT scan last week. She has been charted pain medication. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Cecilia, how’s your pain right now?
[PATIENT]: It’s still there, but manageable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, I’ll keep an eye on your timing and make sure you’re comfortable.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: The Plan is to discharge at the end of this week and Follow‑up with Dr Willow one week post discharge and book a renal outpatients appointment for two weeks after discharge. The discharge summary is at the front of the notes.
[INCOMING_NURSE]:  Are we just waiting on medications to go home?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes we are waiting for the discharge meds from pharmacy.
[INCOMING_NURSE]:  I’ll chase those up.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s quite anxious. Family is in attendance at the moment.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Cecilia, we’ll keep you updated about timing and the medications so you’re not left wondering.
[PATIENT]: I appreciate that. I’ve been a bit worried.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Of course. I’ll check in regularly, and if anything changes with your pain or you have questions, press the call bell.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me. See you tomorrow.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Anything else you’d like us to know or anything you need right now, Cecilia?
[PATIENT]: No, that’s all. Thank you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great—I’ll follow up pharmacy and be back shortly.
