example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Ellie. I’m the day nurse coming on my name is Rupert. I’ll just get handover from Sam, who’s finishing night shift. Is that okay?
[PATIENT]: Sure.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Ellie. This is bed 4, The Patient is Ellie Aline, 23, under Dr. Willow.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Ellie—could you tell us your full name, please? 
[PATIENT]: Ellie Aline.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Your name is spelt wrong and I'll confirm your date of birth in the chart.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Ellie was admitted for an infection of unknown origin—still under investigation. She has a Background of chronic kidney disease.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s been reporting severe pain; she’s on ongoing pain management. She’s ambulant and self-caring on the ward.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Ellie, how’s your pain feeling right now?
[PATIENT]: Still pretty sore, especially when I move.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, we’ll review what you’ve had and top up as appropriate.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She hasn’t been seen by the medical team yet today. Ellie is asking about a weekend leave pass if the team agrees.
[PATIENT]: Yes, if it’s safe, I’d like to go out for a few hours over the weekend.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll raise that with Dr. Willow’s team once they review you.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Obs-wise, she’s been afebrile on my shift and otherwise stable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. I’ll recheck your vitals after handover and monitor while we’re investigating the source of infection.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: I think that everything is up to date.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: So the plan is to continue pain management, encourage safe mobilisation, chase the team for review and investigation plan, and discuss the leave pass request with them.
[PATIENT]: Sounds good. Thank you.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Anything you need before I head off, Ellie?
[PATIENT]: I’m okay for now.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll be back shortly to check your observations and pain meds.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Renata. I’m taking over your care for the day my name is Fred. Do you mind if we do your bedside handover with Jack?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Renata. Could you please confirm your full name?
[PATIENT]: Renata Cola.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks. We’re in room 1, bed 5. Renata is 33 years old and under Dr. Willow.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She was admitted with an acute kidney injury of unknown cause.Her Workup is ongoing. She’s still awaiting a renal ultrasound, and she’s booked for a renal biopsy tomorrow.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Has consent been completed?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Not yet. The consent still needs to be signed. The doctors have already discussed the procedure with her.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, we’ll make sure that’s sorted with the team today.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She's For the biopsy tomorrow,and needs to fast from midnight. All the regular medications can be given with sips of water.
[PATIENT]: Okay, she needs to fast from midnight.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s tolerating diet and fluids well for now and is on a strict fluid balance chart.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll keep the input/output chart up to date.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She also needs a new cannula today.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll arrange a new IV cannula after handover.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s self-caring and mobilises independently around the ward. No other issues to note at the moment.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Renata, do you have any questions or concerns right now?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m okay. Just let me know when the ultrasound is.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll follow up on the ultrasound timing and update you. We’ll also remind you this evening about fasting from midnight.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me. I'm off to the shops. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll get started on the cannula and check on the consent and scan time. Press your call bell if you need anything, Renata.
[PATIENT]: Thank you.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Marco. I’m the incoming nurse. I’ll just get bedside handover from my colleague and then we’ll check in with you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Marco. He’s Bed 6 in Room 1, under Dr. Sun. Admitted with nephrolithiasis—kidney stones.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Marco, can you confirm your full name and age?
[PATIENT]: Marco Calasso, 40.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great, thank you.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He has a background history of depression and asthma. He’s on both oral and IV antibiotics. He’s for a Lithotripsy with Dr. Sun next week.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay what day?

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Wednesday, I think. His Main issues overnight have been pain, it has been severe—he’s rating it 10 out of 10 despite regular Panadol, plus PRN Morphine and Endone.
[PATIENT]: It’s been really strong, yeah.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, Marco, we’ll reassess that right after handover.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He still has haematuria. He also had nausea and vomiting; we gave IV metoclopramide with good effect—settled the nausea.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good to hear the antiemetic helped.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]:He has one IV cannula in the right hand— the site is patent and intact.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll check the site and flush after handover.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Agatha. I’m Priya, I’ll be looking after you today. I’m just getting handover from Sam, is that okay?
[PATIENT]: Yes, that’s fine.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Agatha. So, Bed 1, Agatha Holmes, is 50 years old. She’s come in with an acute kidney injury for investigation.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Agatha, could you confirm your full name and date of birth for us?
[PATIENT]: Agatha Holmes, and it’s 14 July 1974.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s under the nephrology team. There was a note about “other doctor’s… Son” in the referral—think that means Dr Son’s team is consulting as well.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, I’ll confirm teams on the board.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: As a kidney patient she’s on the usual daily bloods, lying and standing blood pressures, daily weights, and weekly urinalysis.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Do we have the pathology forms in the chart?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, the forms are in the chart.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: There are specific times for a few of her tablets—I'll give you a more detailed rundown after the round.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Perfect, I’ll touch base with you for the med timings before the next dose window.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Also, she on a strict fluid chart  And random BGLs while on prednisolone.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Is the pred written up on the med chart?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, it’s charted.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s definitely on a strict fluid balance chart.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: We’ll keep it up to date. Agatha, we’ll be measuring everything you drink and all urine output—if you need any help with the jugs or the pan, just buzz us.
[PATIENT]: Sure, I can do that.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any allergies we should know about, Agatha?
[PATIENT]: No, none that I know of.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any dizziness when standing or going to the bathroom?
[PATIENT]: A little light‑headed when I get up.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks—that fits with the postural checks we’ll be doing. We’ll take it slow and use the call bell before you stand.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me for Agatha right now.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great.so today we need to do bloods, lying/standing BPs, daily weight, continue strict fluid balance, random BGLs on pred, and I’ll come back to confirm those med timing specifics with you, Sam. Agatha, is there anything you need before we go?
[PATIENT]: I’m okay, thank you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: We’ll be back shortly to get your weight and do your blood pressure checks. Press the buzzer if you need us.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Phil. I’m Alex, I’ll be looking after you today. I’m just going to get handover from Sam, is that okay?
[PATIENT]: Sure, that’s fine.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Phil. So, this is Phil Albert Rivet, He's 64 years old, In bed 2, under Dr. Garcia.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Phil, can you confirm your full name for me, and I’ll check your wristband?
[PATIENT]: Phil Albert Rivet.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Phil came in by ambulance four days ago for thrombolytic therapy. He’s got a long history of cardiac problems of about 14 years.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He was on regular GTN on arrival and he’s still on regular GTN as charted.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, so continuing nitrates as per the med chart.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: The obs are stable, and he’s gradually improving. There have been no other problems noted overnight.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Are there any changes in your symptoms, Phil? Any chest pain or shortness of breath right now?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m comfortable at the moment.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good to hear. I’ll keep an eye on your vitals and meds.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s pretty much it from me. He's Stable,and improving, we are continuing with the GTN, and routine obs.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll review the chart and do your next set of obs shortly. Phil, buzz if you need anything.
[PATIENT]: Will do, thanks.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Phil. I’ll head off. Alex, he’s all yours.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Sam.

[PATIENT]: Sure.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Hildy. I'm just here with my colleague to do bedside handover, is that okay?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi there. This is Hildy Hutter in room 4, bed 6, under Dr. Forbes.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hildy, could you tell us your full name and date of birth?
[PATIENT]: Oh… I’m waiting for the bus, dear.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s alright, Hildy. We’ll just check your ID band and IV medications.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hildy is a lovely 91-year-old lady admitted with a urinary tract infection.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s currently on IV antibiotics. The doctors have also charted oral antibiotics to commence tomorrow.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, so the IV ABs running now at 100ml per hour.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes they are Running as charted; the next dose due as per the medication times. I’ve signed the last dose.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s very confused today. Observations have been stable, but she is febrile.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: otherwise she has stable obs but with a temperature. I’ll keep monitoring and encourage fluids as appropriate.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you. No other acute issues to flag at the moment.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hildy, you might feel a bit warm—we’re keeping a close eye on you. Are you in any pain right now?
[PATIENT]: I think I should be going home soon… where’s my coat?
[INCOMING_NURSE]: We’ll help you with that later. For now you’re safe here. The call bell is right by your hand, and we’ll be popping in regularly.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Plan for the shift: continue IV antibiotics as charted, monitor temperature and observations, and oral antibiotics to start tomorrow. We’ll also keep reorienting and maintain falls precautions given the confusion.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. Anything else you need before I head off, Hildy?
[PATIENT]: A cup of tea… maybe.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll check what you can have and come right back.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks for the handover.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No worries. I’m off. See you both later.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Lyndon. I’m Sam, I’ll be looking after you now. I’m just going to get handover from Pat, is that okay?
[PATIENT]: Sure.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Sam. This is Bed 2, Lyndon Basilakis, who is 50 years old, under Dr. Forbes. He came in with severe abdominal pain and fever.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Lyndon, can you confirm your full name and date of birth for us?
[PATIENT]: Lyndon Basilakis, 12th of March, 1974.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great, thank you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: On my shift he’s been afebrile, but he still reports abdominal pain.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. Lyndon, how’s your pain right now, out of 10?
[PATIENT]: About a 6.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: I’ve given pain relief with good effect earlier, and he settled, but it does creep back.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Noted. Any nausea or vomiting?
[PATIENT]: A little nausea, no vomiting.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Also, per team request, we need MRSA and VRE surveillance—I've referred/notified the team for that.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Have the surveillance swabs been taken yet?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Not yet we still need to do them.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, I’ll follow up and get those done.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any other concerns—fluids, IV access, allergies?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No IV access changes to report and no new allergies disclosed to me. Main issue has been the abdominal pain; otherwise afebrile this shift.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Lyndon, I’ll check your observations now, get you something for that pain as due, and I’ll follow up the MRSA/VRE swabs.
[PATIENT]: Thanks.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s all from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Pat. I’ll take it from here.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Benjamin. I'm taking over your care from the night nurse my name is Greg. Is it okay if we do your handover here at the bedside?
[PATIENT]: Sure, that’s fine.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Benjamin. So, this is Benjamin Lincoln 51 years old, under Dr T. Lenny. He was admitted with a query acute kidney injury.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: His Past history includes diabetes and heartburn. He’s for a renal ultrasound at some point today, and a renal biopsy on Thursday.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, I’ll keep an eye out for the ultrasound time and make sure you’re ready to go, Benjamin.
[PATIENT]: Sounds good.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He was febrile last night, up to 37.6 but he’s been afebrile on my shift. Other observations seem ok.
[INCOMING_NURSE]:And you’ve been up and about?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Didn't really have to get up at night so unsure.
[PATIENT]: I’ve been walking around a bit, yes.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Excellent. Any concerns right now—pain, nausea, anything you want us to know about?
[PATIENT]: No, I feel okay at the moment.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Benjamin, I’ll check your obs shortly and keep you updated about the ultrasound time. If you need anything, just press the call bell.
[PATIENT]: Will do, thanks.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, George. I’m Alex, the day nurse. I’m just going to take handover from Maria, who’s been looking after you overnight—okay?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi George. We’ll keep this brief.In Bed 1 is George Antonio Sanchez, he is 43 years old.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi George. I’ll just check your ID band, infusions and iv cannula. The arm band matches George Antonio Sanchez. Thank you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any allergies we should know about?
[PATIENT]: No, none.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: George came in for investigation of high blood pressure. All the tests have been completed; we’re just waiting for the results.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: What was his blood Pressure?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: It was a little high I think. If everything comes back within acceptable limits, he’s clear for discharge today as per the team.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. George, how are you feeling right now—any headache, chest pain, dizziness?
[PATIENT]: I feel fine, no symptoms.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He slept all night, and there have been no other issues overnight.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. I’ll keep an eye on the results and update you as soon as they’re in. If all’s good, we’ll get your discharge sorted. How are you going to get home?
[PATIENT]: My son will pick me up. I have to ring him when I am ready to go.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Okay that's good.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Maria. George, press the call bell if you need anything. I’ll be back shortly.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, handing over Mrs. Margaret Lewis, 85 years old, admitted with Alzheimer’s dementia and depression. She’s under Dr. Singh, Geriatrician.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Can you tell me about her current plan?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She has a dementia care plan in place. She becomes anxious during meals and ADLs, but has a positive Behaviour Support Plan documented in her file — strategies include step-by-step prompting, calm tone of voice, and family involvement at mealtimes.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: What’s her functional status?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She mobilises with a 4-wheel walker and supervision. Needs full assistance with showering and partial assistance with dressing. She eats better when family are present. They’ve been visiting twice daily, which helps settle her.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Current medications?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Escitalopram 10 mg, memantine 10 mg. No known allergies. She’s tolerating meds well.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any monitoring or referrals?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s on food and fluid charts due to poor intake and has mild weight loss over the past 3 months. Awaiting medical review later today and Psych are planning to see her also. She’s also due for physio input to maintain mobility. Bowels charted — last motion yesterday.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. Anything else?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Just maintain orientation, continue strategies from her support plan, and liaise with her family who are due at 10AM. Pressure area care completed. All observations stable.
